characters: I_ HAVE SINNED AND I REPENT --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s 1958. We’re in a lonely motel room. A key hits the lock. A MAN throws open the door and races into the room. He slams the door. He peeks out the window and studies the parking lot. He struggles to catch his breath. We may notice blood on the sleeves of his suit. This is FELIX O’ KELLY. He steps away from the window. He’s carrying a RED DUFFEL BAG. He sets it down and surveys his room.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Felix shoves the bed to the side of the room. [Note: for the duration of this sequence, the camera rema in the same position. Fast jump cuts.] Felix opens his red duffel bag. He removes a crowbar. A hammer. A handgun.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Felix, his jacket off now, yanks up the carpet from the corner of the room, revealing the WOODEN FLOOR BOARDS bel Felix looks at the floor boards. Looks at his tools. Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Felix adjusts THE RADIO antenna. Static. He fiddles with the dial. Fifties folk-pop fills the room as Felix finds station playing “26 Miles” by The Four Preps. Twenty-six miles across the sea, Santa Catalina is a-wait for me... Felix turns up the volume.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Felix hammers the crowbar between slats in the center of room. The sound is somewhat muffled by the radio. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 2.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He pries up the floorboards one by one.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Santa Catalina, the island of romance, romance, romance.. We may notice it’s NIGHT outside now. Felix has his shirtsleeves rolled up. He’s covered in sweat. There’s no a large hole in the floor. The floorboards are all neatly stacked to the side. Felix zips up the duffel bag. We never get a good look at what’s inside. He drops the bag inside the hole.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Felix replaces the floor boards. He hammers the nails in time to the music. He smokes while he works.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Felix rolls the carpet back. Stamps it down in the corner He looks down at the hammer in his hand. Looks at the crowbar on the bed. Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The room is empty now. Through the open door, we can see it’s raining outside. We hear a trunk SLAM.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A soaking wet Felix crawls on his hands and knees and sco up the sawdust on the carpet. He stands. Surveys the room Looks good. Felix catches a glimpse of himself in the LARGE MIRROR mounted on the wall. Looks less good.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Felix stands in front of his mirror. He combs his hair wi a black plastic comb. Twenty-six miles across the sea...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 3.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Felix paces back and forth. He stubs out one cigarette an lights another.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Felix sits in the wooden chair in the corner. He smokes. The ashtray next to him is filled with butts. HEADLIGHTS flare the curtains. Felix stubs out his cigarette. Forty kilometers in a leaky old boat... There’s a knock at the door. Felix grabs the handgun from the night stand. Moves to th peephole. Studies the outside world. Any old thing that'll stay afloat... His shoulders relax when he sees who it is. Felix throws the latch. Opens the door. Gestures for the person to come on in... BOOM. A shotgun BLAST hits Felix O’Kelly square in the ba He’s launched clear across the room, and the second his b SLAMS INTO CAMERA, blood splashing the lens --

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO TITLE
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Over black. Title clears. A new song ("25 Miles”) signals new era. Driving sixties soul as Edwin Starr calls out, “ right, feet, start moving..." TITLE: Ten years later

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The El Royale is a motor lodge nestled in the woods north Lake Tahoe. It once had dreams of being a mid-level vacat hideaway. Those dreams do not appear to have been realize “You've got to get me there...” A wooden arch bears the name of the establishment, welcom visitors to the mostly-empty parking lot. A dented gray Studebaker drives through the arch. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 4.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The defining characteristic of the parking lot is A RED L that bisects the lot dead center and leads straight to th double doors of the lobby lodge. “It's twenty-five miles from home..." The Studebaker parks. The driver opens her door. We get a better look at her: Late thirties. African-American. As she stares at the El Royale, we can almost hear her thinking, “How in the Lord name did I end up in this lonely place?” This is DARLENE SWEET. She opens her trunk and removes HER ODD BAGS. One is a la flowered suitcase. The other appears to be an enormous ro of fabric, bound with a rope around it. It would be too much luggage for a lumberjack, let alone Darlene. But she lifts the burden without complaint, balancing one in each arm. As she approaches the lodge, she notices A MAN standing i the parking lot: He’s in his sixties. He’s wearing a priest collar. He’s staring at the hotel. He looks lost and confused. This is FATHER DANIEL FLYNN. Darlene slows when she sees him.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Are... you lost, Father? Flynn almost jumps when he hears her. His eyes become cle again, as though he just awoke from a dream. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: No. No, I suppose not. (looks down) According to this, I’m in Nevada. ON THE GROUND: the RED LINE runs right between them. On t west side of the line, stenciled letters read “California On the east side of the line, “Nevada.”

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: (smiles ) I’ve never been to Nevada. What’s it like? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 5.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Not bad. Looks like it might rain. What’s California like? Darlene looks over her shoulder to the west.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Still sunny. Flynn picks up his valise.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Can I give you a hand there?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: That's very kind of you, thank you. She hands him the flowered suitcase. If Flynn is curious about the strange roll of fabric in Darlene’s arms, he gi no indication. They walk towards the motel. The border leads straight to set of doors, one door on each side of the line. They enter through the California side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ring-ring. The front door chimes as Darlene and Flynn ent and study the unique accommodations: The interior of the El Royale plays on the same border th The line bisects the large room perfectly in two. ON THE CALIFORNIA SIDE: everything is decorated in warm orange hues. We may notice a bar, a set of tables, a loun seating area. ON THE NEVADA SIDE: everything is decorated in cool purpl hues. We may notice the front desk, some gaming tables, a black and white television currently showing coverage of Richard Nixon’s 1969 inauguration speech. At the back of the room, half in California and half in Nevada, is a colorful JUKEBOX. Flynn looks down at the border, Darlene follows his gaze. They're both standing in California. Flynn gestures: be m guest. Darlene smiles. Takes a mock deep breath... And steps across the border. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 6.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: How are you enjoying Nevada so far? Darlene shrugs. So far, so good.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Those are my accoutrements... The voice has a thick Mississippi accent. It’s coming fro behind the bar on the California side. A man wearing a charmingly rumpled seersucker suit reveals himself: This is LARAMIE SEYMOUR SULLIVAN.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: (points) At the front desk there. They look to the front desk, where a large amount of lugg has been piled.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s my trunk, that’s my fortnighter, that’s my hat case. And I’d ask that you folk respect my claim when it comes time to divvy the rooms. Though when that'll be is anyone’s guess. I been ringin’ that bell so long my hand’s sore and my ears is tired and my constitution needs coffee. So. That’s why I’m back here scroungin’. He holds up a pack of coffee grounds. He dumps it into th elaborate machine behind the counter.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Success! Though I can’t say I vouch for the quality. He starts the machine. While it grinds and grumbles, Lara crosses the room, extends his hand to Flynn.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Laramie Seymour Sullivan. Sales manager, Calhoun Appliances. My name may not be on the masthead, but that don’t mean it ain’t a family business. He hands Flynn a business card. Tips his hat to Darlene. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 7.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: What should I call you, Father?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Daniel Flynn. It is nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Father Flynn, huh. That’s easy to remember, alliterative and such. Whereabouts is your parish?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: The Immaculate Heart of Mary’s in Bloomington, Indiana. A beat as Laramie sizes up Flynn.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Well. (then) Let me just say up front that me and the good people of East Biloxi Baptist may have our differences with your Pope, but in our hearts we both believe in the divinity of Jesus Christ, and that makes us brothers as far as I’m concerned. Who handles your hospitality at the Heart of Mary?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: You know, who keeps the place clean and tidy?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Her... name is Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Could I trouble you for Barbara’s phone number? I believe the good Lord has put me in your path to make her life easier. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 8.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Flynn studies Laramie. Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I confess my memory is not what it used to be. But I have it written down in my valise. I'd be happy to get it for you once I check-in and am squared away.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: I'd sure appreciate it. Though, again, Lord only knows when that'd be. He points to the brass bell on the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can go ahead and give it a whirl. I ain’t had much luck with it. (turns) How ‘bout you, darlin’ -- you in the hospitality business? Darlene seems genuinely taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I -- how did you know my name?

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Your name is “Darlin’?” Ain’t that a pip! And they say fate died in ‘63. Darlene realizes the mistake.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry. I thought you said... never mind. I’m not in the hospitality business. No.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Well, I’1l give you my card nonetheless. I’m sure you know some gals who need a vacuum. A beat. Then Father Flynn rings the bell. The group waits in awkward silence. No response. Laramie rolls his eyes: see what I mean? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 9.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This your first time at the El Royale? Both Flynn and Darlene nod. Laramie crosses back to the b

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It didn't always used to be like this. And I don’t jus’ mean you could find the clerk come check-in. Naw, this place used to be hustlin’ and bustlin’. Tahoe’s best kept secret. I mean, it was always a novelty, but there’s state fair novelty and old horse novelty and we are now firmly in the old horse variety. He removes the coffee carafe from the machine and grabs t cups. As he starts making his way back across the room:

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘66 this place had swing. Hell, I’m sure I couldn’t get a main lodge room if I tried. He points to the photographs adorning the California wall

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was a hidey hole for the Tahoe swells. Darlene looks at the photos. The El Royale in more boisterous times. There’s Frank Sinatra lounging by the pool. There’s Martin Luther King, Jr. shaking hands with crowd of well-wishers. There’s Bobby Kennedy making pop- superstar VESTA SHEARS laugh.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dean Martin even sang a song about it. “Half In California With Judy?” (off their looks) No? (shrugs) Wasn’t one of his best. Coffee? Flynn nods. Sure. Darlene shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: No, thank you. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 10.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Aw, come on. I made a whole pot. Can’t let it go to waste. He hands her a cup. Take it. She relents.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (as he pours) Atta girl. I'll let the clerk give you the whole spiel, should he ever show up, I mean. But the part they tend to leave out is about, oh, a year ago this place lost its gambling license. Some problems with the commission or something. And so the swells took their business elsewhere. Now the main lodge is all that’s open and the pool is filled with ducks and they rent rooms by the hour if you ask quiet-like. (then) ‘Course, if we’re bein’ honest, that’s probably why a priest, a vacuum salesman, and a Negro can afford freight here, right Father? (laughs) I’m just funnin’. My stay’s on Calhoun Appliances, if I’m bein’ truthful, which is why room choice is so important and I ask you to respect my accoutrements there as a proxy for my person. I intend to lavish myself. Always wanted to stay in The Honeymoon Suite. He holds up his left hand. His ring finger is bare.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Though I am not currently on my honeymoon. They wait in awkward silence. They sip their coffee. A light bulb goes off over Flynn's head. As though he’s b thinking about something else this entire time:

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Oh. (turns) “Darlene.” Darlene nods. Smiles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 11.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) Nice to meet you, Darlene.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you too, Father.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Well, hell. We have to wait much longer, I might as well open up that there trunk and set up the Calhoun Electrovax. Give you folks a proper demonstration. You sure you ain’t in the hospitality business, darlin’? Darlene, once again, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: No, sir. I am not. She walks behind the front desk to THE DOOR that says “Employees Only.” Gives it a proper thumping with her fis Wham wham wham. There’s a THUD from behind the door.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Ho! The lady’s got a luckier hand than we do, Father. Shame these here tables is decommissioned, we could make ourselves some real money. We hear fumbling. Footsteps. The door finally swings open revealing a twenty-year-old kid with a baby face and an i fitting desk clerk jacket. He looks a bit like a wet rat. This is MILES MILLER.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I’m very sorry to keep you waiting. If you had to guess how long it has been since Miles has slept, you'd probably go with “Five days.”

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Damn, boy, I been in this lobby so long, I’m due for a shave. What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 12.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Miles stops cold. If it’s possible for him to go paler, h does when he sees Father Flynn. MILES (CONT’D) Wh... what are you doing here, Father? Flynn seems genuinely unsettled.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Do I know you, son?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: No. But... I mean... this is not a place for a priest, Father. You shouldn’t be here.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: We may need to work on your sales pitch, boy. “The El Royale: Ain't No Place For A Priest.”

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: There are other hotels, Father. Maybe closer to Tahoe? I could help you find one, I’m sure you'd be happier there. Flynn recovers. Smiles a patronly smile. Looks at Miles’ name tag.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: “Miles,” is it? If this is not a place for a priest, Miles, then this is exactly where the Lord wants me.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Well, the Lord don’t want you in The Honeymoon Suite, I promise you that much. Miles, those is my accoutrements there, and I stake my claim as such. But you can go ahead and check them in first for all I care. (looks in mirror, rubs chin) Any luck I'll have a full Jeb Stuart by the time we’re done. Miles looks back and forth between Laramie and Flynn. He continues to seem genuinely anxious. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 13.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: It’s all right, son.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Go ahead, boy. Give ‘em the spiel. “The El Royale...”

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: The El Royale is a bi-state establishment. You have the option to stay in either the great state of California OR the great state of Nevada. Which would you prefer?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: What’s the difference?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Between California and Nevada?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Between the rooms.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Well, for starters, rooms in California cost a dollar more.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: (whistles) Shoot. Really. When that happen? What makes ‘em a dollar better?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: They're in California.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: And that’s worth a dollar?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Some people think so.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: You got a number for those people? ‘Cause I got a vacuum they might be interested in. Speaking of which! Who’s your Head of Hospitality here?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Currently that is also me. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 14.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: (grimaces) Well. Then let’s worry about that later then.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: May I see a map of the hotel? Miles nods. He pulls out A MAP. From above, the El Royale looks like an upside-down “U” with the parking lot in the middle. As Father Flynn looks it over --

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Only the main lodge is available in the off-season. (then) You can still use the California amenities if you choose to stay in Nevada.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: (chuffs) What exactly is a “California amenity?”

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: For instance, we are not allowed to sell liquor in Nevada.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Lost that when you lost your gamblin’ license? So, you’re saying, if we want to drink, we gotta do it on this side of the room?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: That’s correct, sir. Also, coffee is twenty-five cents a cup.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Let me guess, you’re also the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: That’s correct, sir. Laramie rolls his eyes. Removes a quarter from his pocket Slaps it on the desk next to Flynn, who seems genuinely rattled by the map. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 15.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Feel free to flip that if you need to make a decision, Father. Starting to cost me money waitin’ around here. The quiet of the lobby is suddenly disturbed by the ROAR an engine from outside. All four people turn towards the windows to see a GREEN DODGE CHARGER scream into the lot. Tires SQUEAL as the Charger screeches to a stop. Flynn turns his attention back to the map. Shakes his hea Picks up Laramie’s quarter and flips it. Heads. Shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I‘1l take Room Four. Miles looks away from the window. Gets a key from the wal behind him. Laramie moves closer to the window for a better look. IN CAR: we can make out A WOMAN in the driver’s seat. She se to be watching the road behind her intently.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I‘1l need one night in advance. Eight dollars. And twenty-five cents for the coffee. Please sign the ledger. There’s a large leather ledger on the desk. Flynn takes o $8.25 and puts it on the counter. Picks up the fountain p CLOSE AS HE SIGNS: Father Daniel Flynn. MILES (CONT’D) Who’s next? Laramie is still interested in the car outside. He gestur to Darlene. Go ahead. She steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I'd like a room in Nevada, please. Miles nods. Grabs a key. Slaps it on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Room Five.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Oh. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 16.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then) Is there another room available, possibly? Further away. Maybe at the end? OUTSIDE: the car door slams. The WOMAN starts walking towards the lodge. She’s in a hurry. Laramie turns his attention back to the desk.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: These rooms have not been serviced and are unsuitable.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: He does the housekeeping, remember.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: There are rooms in California available, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: (losing patience) She doesn’t want to be near the priest. Flynn, who was collecting his belongings and moving to ex stops in his tracks. I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Flynn) Like we don’t see her walkin’ in here with her own bedrolls under her arms. (to Darlene) Don’t worry, darlin’, we ain’t here to judge. Father here can even teach you ‘bout Mary Magdalene and forgiveness and what not. Darlene’s eyes flash with embarrassment and anger. Ring-ring. Right then, the woman from outside walks into El Royale. She's in her late twenties. Looks to be a card-carrying member of the flower generation. She’s trying her best no to look distressed. And failing. This is EMILY SUMMERSPRING. Emily stops in her tracks, not expecting to find this man people in the lobby. What did I just walk into? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 17.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Darlene turns her attention back to Miles, eager to get o of there. She takes a small coin purse from her jacket an counts out eight one-dollar bills.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Room Five will be fine.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Please sign the ledger. And it’s twenty-five cents for the coffee. Darlene’s eyes instinctively look to Laramie. He’s not making eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Okay. Of course. As she starts to reach for her coin purse. Clack. A hand puts a quarter on the desk. Darlene sees it belongs to Flynn. He nods. It’s on me. Darlene nods back. Thank you. She grabs the pen. CLOSE ON THE LEDGER as she writes: Darlene Sweet. She grabs her bags.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Can I give you a hand to your room?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: No. She stops herself, realizing this man is not the one who deserves her anger.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry, Father. That’s kind of you. But I can manage from here. Ring. Laramie makes a show of holding the door for her.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: (tips hat) Ma’am. Flynn waits a beat. Gathers his valise. Moves to leave. Nods to Emily as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: Afternoon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 18.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She gives him a curt nod. Ring. Flynn exits. And then there were three. Miles looks to both of them. Who's next? Laramie just shakes his head. Throws up his hands.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Please. Be my fuckin’ guest. (yells to window) Sorry, Father. Emily shrugs. Fine. I'll go. Steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I need a room.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: The El Royale is a bi-state establishment. You have the option to choose a room in either -- She grabs the map from the desk. Studies it. Taps it.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I‘1ll take that one. Miles looks down at her choice. His shoulders slump just slightly. His weary eyes look back to Laramie.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Don’t fuckin’ tell me. Emily removes a large wad of cash from her jeans.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I‘1l take Room One.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: You can’t have Room One. Emily turns and stares at him. Defiant. Why not?

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you see my fortnighter right there at your feet? Is this really happening? (to Miles) Am I really about to explain the concept of a free market claim stake to the goddamn hippie? Emily just stares at him with cold eyes. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 19.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then she relents. Turns back to the map.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Give me something along this wall.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: The available rooms on that wall have yet to be cleaned.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I don’t give a shit. How much?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Eight dollars. She peels off eight dollars. He puts a key on the desk. Room Seven. She reaches for it. He slides it away. MILES (CONT’D) Please sign the ledger. Emily stares at him. Really? He stares back. Yes. She grabs the pen. Scrawls something fast. Grabs the key. Heads towards the door. Ring.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: You have yourself a pleasant day, now. Laramie steps forward. Finally. He grabs the pen. Looks down at the ledger. Sees Emily’s signature.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice. CLOSE ON THE LEDGER: Fuck You. Laramie signs his name at the bottom of the page. CLOSE ON THE LEDGER as he writes with flourish: Laramie Seymour Sullivan. CLOSE ON LARAMIE as he looks up at Miles and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l take Room One. CUT TO BLACK. TITLE: Room One  Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the sound of a key jangling. Click. Laramie enter hits the lights. He carries his accoutrements into the ro Takes off his hat and jacket. Folds the jacket carefully lays it over the back of a chair. Rolls up his white shir sleeves. Studies the room. The Honeymoon Suite is on the California side of the bord and thus decorated in warm orange hues. It would never be described as luxurious by any means, but it does have a notable king bed on a raised platform and a jacuzzi tub i the floor. CLOSE SHOTS: locks flip. A suitcase swings open, revealin neatly folded clothes. Everything feels regimented. A han removes A DOPP KIT. CLOSE SHOTS: items are placed along a sink. A toothbrush. soap case. A small bottle of shampoo. A hair tonic. All meticulously ordered just so. CLOSE SHOTS: locks flip. The trunk swings open, revealing the Calhoun Electrovax. The vacuum is removed. Click. A false bottom is removed from the trunk. A BLACK BRIEFCASE removed and placed on the bed. The briefcase swings open, revealing an array of SMALL TOOLS. CLOSE SHOTS: a pair of glasses are removed from a case. Laramie sits on the bed. In his shirtsleeves and wirefram glasses now, he looks a far cry from the seersucker southerner we met moments ago. He removes a pair of pliers and a screwdriver from the ca He thinks of something. He checks his watch. Does a small double take. Picks up the phone and dials it. Listens. Then.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE
dialogues.text: Hi, my love. I know, I know... check-in took a little longer than I expected... And as Laramie talks, we may notice that his thick Mississippi accent is now GONE.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is she still up? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 21.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: While Laramie waits, he takes the screwdriver and begins unscrew the baseplate of the phone receiver. He works quickly, with clinical precision.

dialogues.speaker: LARAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi rabbit! I know, I’m sorry. I got delayed. Yes, the clock is right. Daddy's wrong. And between the accent, the wife, the child, and the tool it should obvious that this man has not been honest about he is. In fact, we should probably start calling him by h real name. This is not Laramie Seymour Sullivan... This is DWIGHT BROADBECK.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: But I got you before you went down. Ready? Of course. I’m on my knees. Dwight pulls off the baseplate, flips the housing over. Looks under the receiver...

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Now I lay me down to sleep, pray the Lord my soul to keep...” Dwight removes a SMALL BLACK MICROPHONE from the receiver Holds it up to the light. Nods, pleased. He sets it down the night stand.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “And if I should die before I wake, I pray the Lord --” (listens) What do you mean we’re not saying that anymore? (listens) How do you even know what “morbid” means -- what does Mommy want us to say? Dwight begins to reassemble the phone.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. “When I wake in the morning light --" Okay, okay, from the beginning... Dwight frowns. Something’s WRONG. He holds the receiver u to the light to get a better look. Grabs his pliers. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 22.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Now I lay me down to sleep, pray the Lord my soul to keep. And when I wake in the morning light...” Dwight removes something else from the phone with the pli Holds it up to the light.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Teach me to do what’s right.” It’s another microphone. This one’s different than the other. Smaller. Tan in colo Dwight stares at it, confused. Clearly troubled.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Amen. (then) I gotta go, Rabbit. Tell Mommy I love her, okay? (listens) A couple days. I love you. He hangs up. Places the tan bug on the night stand next t the black bug. Stares at the two different microphones. His eyes narrow. He looks to the rest of the room.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Dwight stands on the armchair. Unscrews the wall sconce. Reaches behind the light with a pair of pliers. CLOSE SHOT: an identical black bug is placed beside the first. Dwight pulls the light fixture from the wall. Frowns. CLOSE SHOT: an identical tan bug is placed beside the fir

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Dwight’s in the bathroom now. Covered in sweat. Unscrews the light. Frowns. CLOSE SHOT: Four black bugs are now on the night stand. Dwight’s hand places a fourth tan bug in the row beneath And then a fifth tan bug.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 23.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dwight stands in the center of the room. Arms folded. Staring at the night stand covered in surveillance bugs. Deep in thought. He shakes his head. None of this makes sense. He turns. Something catches his attention. And the hair stands up o the back of Dwight’s neck. We follow his gaze... To the large MIRROR mounted on the back wall. In the reflection, he can see a full view of the bed in t center of the room. Dwight stares at the mirror. Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE: A brown shoe steps carefully through the pine twig A second shoe steps directly in front of it, placing heel front of toe. Dwight, still in shirtsleeves and glasses, walks carefull along the east edge of the El Royale. Heel-to-toe. Heel-t toe. Heel-to-toe. He's measuring the hotel. Dwight reaches the corner. Folds his arms. Stares at the hotel. Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ring-ring. Dwight steps into the lobby. Looks the place over. It’s empty. The black and white television is still on, casting flickering pale light all around the room. ON THE TELEVISION: a SPECIAL NEWS REPORT breaks into the Nixon coverage. We see shots of police cars outside a lar mansion. News logo reads: “Malibu Beach Massacre.” Dwight opens the front desk drawer. Sees the room keys. Spots THE MASTER. He takes it. Dwight unlocks the door marked “Employees Only.” He eases the door open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight steps into the narrow hallway. We can hear music coming from somewhere. “Bend Me Shape Me” by The American Breed. Dwight surveys. At the far end of the hallway, there’s a HEAVY METAL DOOR. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 11 12 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 24.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Closer to Dwight, there’s another door with the words “MAINTENANCE CLOSET.” “Bend me shape me anyway you want me..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight eases the door open, looks into the room. His face falls. Reverse to reveal -- A cramped closet. A cot. A hot plate. A transistor radio. And Miles. Passed out cold. Slumped against the wall. A bent spoon on the floor beside him. A syringe still hangi from his bloodied arm. “As long as you love me, it's all right..." Dwight closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight approaches the HEAVY GRAY DOOR at the end of the hallway. Tries the handle. It’s LOCKED. He tries THE MASTER KEY. It doesn’t work. Dwight reaches into his pocket. Pulls out a case of LOCKPICKS. Drops to his knees. Works the lock. Click.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight steps into a dimly-lit corridor. Shuts the door behind him. Music stops. The world goes silent. Dwight steps carefully down the corridor. At the end of t corridor, the corridor branches. West or East. Dwight chooses West. Careful not to make a sound. Rounds the corner... And finds the mirror. Or, rather, the OBSERVATION WINDOW. perfectly framed rectangle looking into a hotel room. Specifically... His hotel room. He stares at Room One. Arms folded. Thinks. Looks down at the feet. Takes note of THREE SCUFF MARKS on the floor.  13 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight enters the East Corridor. Looking for something. There. Way down at the other end of the hall. It looks like... A 16MM CAMERA. Mounted on a tripod. [Note: from this point forward, this entire scene will be done _in ONE CONTINUOUS TAKE. ]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight starts walking down the hall. Passes ANOTHER OBSERVATION WINDOW. The room’s dark. Dwight squints. Seems empty. Dwight keeps moving. We track with him. Watc him STOP SHORT when he gets to the next window. Room Four. As Dwight stares, we angle around to reveal: FATHER DANIE FLYNN. Unaware that he’s being watched, Father Flynn's bu shoving his twin bed up against the wall. He reaches into his valise, pulls out what looks like A CROWBAR and A HAM He goes to the corner of the room... And starts yanking the carpet free of the tacks. Dwight stares. The corridor eerily silent as the priest works. Father Flynn yanks an entire swath of the carpet free, exposing the old wood boards underneath. Flynn takes the crowbar... and starts hammering it into t floorboards. Dwight can’t believe what he’s seeing. What the hell is t old priest doing? Dwight watches in silence for a second. Then turns his attention back towards THAT CAMERA. Keeps moving. But sto in his tracks yet again when he passes... Room Five. Darlene Sweet’s room. And, yes, there she is... Also doing something strange. She's standing on her dresser, trying to hang what looks a large swath of fabric on her west wall. She has thumbta in her mouth, she uses them to secure the fabric in place She hops off the dresser. Grabs another roll. Goes back t work hanging it on the wall. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 26.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And she unrolls it, Dwight realizes this fabric is the “bedding” Darlene was carrying earlier. It’s not bedding all... It’s soundproofing foam. Darlene fastens the last piece in place. Steps back and surveys her handiwork. Her look seems to say: Well, it's great, but it'll do. Darlene reaches into her bag. Removes A METRONOME. Sets i on her table beside her. Sits down. Starts the metronome. The pendulum rod starts to swing back and forth, but we c hear anything. Darlene closes her eyes. She takes a deep breath. Her lips start to move. It looks like she’s singing. Dwight frowns. Looks down. Notices, there, below the window... A SPEAKER. And a SWITCH. Dwight flips the switch. Darlene’s voice fills the corrid

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I try hard to hide, my hurt inside, this ol’ heart of mine, always keeps me crying... Dwight jumps. The singing is LOUD. He half expects someon else to hear him. Instinctively looks to the corridor. Nobody’s coming. He turns his attention back to Darlene. Her rendition of The Isley Brothers’ “This Old Heart of M is haunting. No music. Just HER VOICE and the click of th metronome. Dwight watches. Transfixed. Then, concerned, he walks back to... Room Four. And there’s Father Flynn. Standing waist deep in the floorboards of his room. Perfectly still. He’s staring at the wall next to him. DARLENE (0.S.) (CONT’D) Maybe it's my mistake to show this love I feel inside... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 27.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Father Flynn slowly climbs out of his floor. Empty handed He walks to the wall. Puts his ear up against it. Listens Dwight walks back down the corridor. Room Five. Darlene’s belting it out now. Swaying in time to the musi Clapping.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘But I... I love you. This ol’ heart... is weak for you. Dwight stares for a moment longer. Then remembers... THAT CAMERA. Starts moving down the hallway. Room Six. Empty. Room Seven. Also empty. But seems to be inhabited. There’s a bag on t dresser. And ROPE. And A HUNTING KNIFE. Dwight stops. Frowns. And just then... Emily kicks open the door to Room Seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight jumps. Surprised. Emily hurries into the room. Dragging something heavy. It almost looks like A PERSON. Emily kicks the door shut behind her. Carries her burden RIGHT UP CLOSE to the observation window. Dumps it in A CHAIR. It’s a person, all right... This is ROSE. She’s unconscious. Looks to be about eighteen years old. Waifish. Half-dressed. She slumps forward, her head hits the mirror. Thump. Dwight instinctively edges backwards. DARLENE (0.S.) (CONT’D) This ol' heart of mine been broke a thousand times, each time you break away... Emily stares at the unconscious body in the chair. Breath hard. She looks scared. She runs her hands though her hai The look on her face says what do I do next? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 28.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She grabs the knife. She grabs the rope. She starts lashing Rose to the chair. This all happens RIGHT UP CLOSE TO THE WINDOW. Emily cuts the rope, ties Rose to the chair. Steps back. Thinks. Grabs a bandana. Uses it to GAG Rose. Rose never flutters. Out cold. Dwight watches. Stunned. Can’t believe what he’s watching He tells himself to stay on task. Keeps walking. Room Eight. End of the line. Empty. But the 16 MM Camera is there. Mounted on the tripod. Dwight studies the camera. Opens t case. It’s empty. No film. Dwight turns. Looks back down the hall from where he came Thinks. Then. Starts walking back. Room Seven. There’s Rose. Unconscious and bound. Right up close to th glass. Dwight stops. Stares at her. Gets close to her. Puts his hand on the window. Keep moving, Dwight. He starts back down the hall. Moving faster. Room Five. There’s Darlene. On her feet now. Swaying and clapping an dancing.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You_got me never knowing if I'm coming or going but -- Click. Dwight flips the speaker. The corridor goes SILENT We see Darlene still singing. Dwight doesn’t break stride Room Four. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 14 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 29.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dwight passes. Exits frame. We HOLD on the observation window. There’s Father Flynn. He’s taken a chair and placed it against the wall he shares with Darlene’s room. He sits with the back of his head against the wall. Looki to the ceiling. Hands in his lap. He listens to Darlene sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight exits the lobby doors. Moving fast. With purpose. Doesn’t even look up as the RUMBLE of THUNDER overhead signals an incoming STORM. He’s heading to the other side of the parking lot. Where lonely PAYPHONE stands beside the gate. He grabs the phone. Dials a number from memory.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Director's office. Case 246673. Dwight waits. RUMBLE. That thunder clap makes Dwight look up. Pat pat pat... The first drops of RAIN start to fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight straightens up as a voice answers on the other end

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Director Hoover. This is Special Agent Broadbeck. I’m on site at the El Royale. CLOSE ON DWIGHT as he stares back at the hotel. Rumble.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir, we have a problem. CUT TO BLACK. TITLE: Room Five OVER BLACK, we hear the upbeat tempo of The Crystals sing “He’s A Rebel...”

dialogues.speaker: THE CRYSTALS
dialogues.text: See the way he walks down the street...  15 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A genuine WALL OF SOUND hits us as we find ourselves movi through a SIXTIES RECORDING STUDIO in full swing: There’s the LIVE BAND. The DRUMMER snapping the snare. Th PIANIST tapping out that iconic rhythm. The SAX PLAYER waiting to come on in... Over there... in the isolation booth... there’s the lead singer. Her name is VESTA SHEARS. She’s in her early twenties, and in six months Dick Clark is gonna call her future of pop music” on live television. But for now, she’s singing her heart out while THE MEN BE THE GLASS watch.

dialogues.speaker: VESTA SHEARS
dialogues.text: My he holds his head up high when he goes walking by-y-y-y... We keep moving through the studio... There’s THE THREE BA SINGERS. We’re moving down the line of them as they sing their parts. All wearing bright, colorful dresses. All sporting bouffant hairdos.

dialogues.speaker: BACKUP SINGERS
dialogues.text: Qo0000.... OOO00O... And THERE... at the end of the backup trio, is a face we recognize... There’s DARLENE SWEET. She looks at least ten years younger, even though the rea is only half that. She’s wearing a green dress. Her eyes are closed. Lost in the music. Smiling bright as she belt it out:

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: He's a rebel and he'll never ever be... any good... There, watching her through the window, that’s British wunderkind producer BUDDY SUNDAY himself. He’s dressed in his standard Savile Row suit and scarf. His arms are crossed. He’s glowering. Staring right at Darlene. Even though she’s only the third backup singer i this whole elaborate affair. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 31.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But he’s not a rebel, no no no, he's not a rebel, no no --

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY, (FROM THE BOOTH)
dialogues.text: Cut. Cut. Cut it. They all stop playing. Buddy looks exasperated. BUDDY (FROM THE BOOTH) (CONT’D) Let’s take a break, everyone. Darlene... a word. The other singers give Darlene sympathetic looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The musicians file out of the studio as Buddy enters. Darlene watches as he stops Vesta before she leaves. He c her cheek. Tender. Nurturing. We can barely make out thei conversation:

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: «--no, no, you were brilliant. This is why I have you tracked solo.

dialogues.speaker: VESTA SHEARS
dialogues.text: I can come in stronger...

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I don't want you thinking, pet. I want you to stay in this -- (waves his hand over her body ) And let me worry about the knobs and dials. Okay? Now. Get some air. This'll be but a minute. Vesta exits. Leaving Darlene alone with Buddy. Buddy approaches. His eyes go cold as he studies Darlene. Lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where were you last night?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I’m very sorry. I wasn’t feeling well. I called your house and spoke with your... butler. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 32.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Valet.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: He said he would give you the message. I figured I should rest. So I could be fresh today.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Is that your assessment of your performance thus far? “Fresh?”

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I... I don’t know, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I told you, please, call me Buddy. Or Mr. Sunday, if you must. But never Mr. Buddy. Impossible not to make that sound patronizing. Sounds like a chocolate bar. Do you know how much my time is worth, Darlene?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: No, sir. Mr. Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Columbia Records does. He points to the paperwork he has spread out on the mix console.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Columbia Records currently values my time at two hundred dollars an hour. Are you currently ina position where you can turn down two... four... six hundred dollars when it is offered to you?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: No. I am not.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Six hundred dollars of my time. But, instead, you wanted to stay fresh. Which, apparently, means flat on the intro and sharp on the harmonies. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 17 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 33.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I'll get it right, Mr. Sunday. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Do you know how much your time is worth, Darlene?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Twelve dollars a session.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: No matter how long the session. Which, I suppose, means the longer I keep you, the less your time is worth. He offers her a cigarette. She politely declines.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have a choice here, Darlene. Give me one year of your time. And I can make you a star. You’ll be singing lead. You'll be staying at The Carlyle. You'll be headlining the Riviera. Or. You can continue to treat my time as disposable. And you can keep scrounging for twelve dollar backup gigs until they dry up. And in five years you'll find yourself shuffling between shit hotels, begging for the opening slot on waffle night in... (shudders ) Reno. (then) All right. Darlene? Do we understand? CLOSE ON DARLENE as we PRELAP the sound of tick... tick.. tick... tick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAME FRAMING. Darlene sits in silence as the metronome sw back and forth. Tick... tick... tick... tick... She reaches out, stops the metronome. Silence. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 34.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks at her luggage. Her suitcase is open. Something catches her eye. She reaches in, pulls out HER SHOW DRESS Holds it up. She notices the seam is split. Her shoulders slump. This will have to be sewn. We get the sense this happens a lot. There’s a KNOCK at the door. Darlene jumps in surprise. Who could that be? She frowns.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN, (THOUGH DOOR)
dialogues.text: Hello, Darlene? It’s Father Flynn. From earlier. She leaves the chain intact. Opens the door. Father Flynn looks at her through the crack. Behind him, the rain is beginning to pour.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry. I was making too much noise, wasn’t I?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: No, no. Not at all...

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I have a show tomorrow, and I have to rehearse, I tried to make it quiet, but... (shakes head) I’m so sorry. I won’t bother you. I'll figure something out.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: It’s no bother. Quite the opposite, actually. It’s lovely.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: What was that you were singing? Did you write that?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: No. No -- that’s The Isley Brothers. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 35.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There’s a rumble of thunder on her line.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Your brothers wrote that?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: No. (smiles ) It’s a famous song. It’s been on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Oh. (sorry) I don’t know much about the radio these days.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I’m very sorry, Father. I promise I'll keep it --

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I’m gonna go find some food. In the lounge. I thought I’d see if you want to join? With this place, there’s probably strength in numbers.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Oh. No, that’s all right.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: You sure? On me. You can consider it payment for earlier. For letting me listen to you sing.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: That's... (softens) That's a very nice thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ding. The lounge is empty. Flynn and Darlene wait for a moment, just to see if anyone arrives. Nobody arrives.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Why even have a bell?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I suspect we’re on our own. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 36.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Flynn reaches into his pocket. Slaps a handful of pocket change on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I handle food, you handle entertainment?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Deal. Darlene takes a couple quarters, glances at the televisio the desk.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: Police are still searching for suspects in the grisly murder of a Beverly Hills banker and his -- Darlene shudders. Click. She turns off the television. Flynn makes his way over to the California side of the ro Notices THE FIREPLACE. Come to think of it, it is a littl chilly in here... Darlene heads towards the jukebox.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: So you've really never heard of The Isley Brothers? Flynn shakes his head as he strikes a match and lights th fireplace. Darlene makes her way to THE JUKEBOX: a beautiful Wurlitz bubbler stocked full of .45s.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then we have some work to do. (scans) How ‘bout The Four Tops? You've heard of them.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: (thinks ) I’m aware there is a group called The Four Tops. But that’s about as much as I got.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Well. Then. You are in for it. She puts in a quarter. Loads up some selections. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 37.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I almost envy you. “I Got a Feeling” by The Four Tops starts to play. “When you're in my arms... oh when you're in my arms..." Darlene sways a bit. Flynn nods. I like it.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How you making out over there? Flynn is standing in front of a 1950s sandwich vending machine.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I think you’re better at your job than I am at mine. Darlene walks over. Sees the vending carousels of food. Sandwiches, fruit, pastries. Everything looks gray.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Oof.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: How lucky are you feeling tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Definitely not eat-that-sandwich- lucky. They stare at the machine. Music plays.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Pie?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Pie works. CLOSE SHOTS: Quarters drop. Pie spins. Flynn and Darlene sit in the banquet on the California si of the room. They eat their pie. It’s not bad. They both bop their heads to the music.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You really never heard this before?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: (shrugs) My knowledge of what’s going on ends somewhere in the fifties. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 38.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At a certain point, you get left behind. It’s good, though.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: You gotta listen to something.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: We got a pretty good choir at the Heart of Mary.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: That’s how I got started. Church choir. St. Paul’s Evangelical in Decatur. Lutheran. We don’t have to get into all that, though.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: (smiles ) You're forgiven.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I’m sure we sing some of the same stuff. Let’s see... you got “Nearer My God to Thee?” “Alleluia! Sing to Jesus?” Flynn nods. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How about “Lift Me In Your Arms, Hold Me On High?” That was my first solo. You got that? (sings) “Lift me in your arms, hold me on high..." Flynn shifts uncomfortably in his seat. He seems almost embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: To be honest... my memory isn’t quite what it was.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. They sit in awkward silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I think I’m going to have a toddy. Can I interest you? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 39.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: You sure? Nothing like whiskey on a cold night.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I’m fine. Flynn stands up and heads to the bar. CLOSE SHOTS: The record ends. The jukebox switches out th -45. “Bernadette” by The Four Tops starts to play.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (smiles ) This one. This is a record. She lip syncs along. “Bernadette, people are searchin’ fo the kind of love that we possessed..." CLOSE SHOTS: Whiskey pours into a glass. A pencil writes “I.0.U. - Whiskey” then makes a slash next to it. Flynn sits back down. Takes a drink of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: That's where you're from? Georgia?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Illinois. People make that mistake all the time. I’m not quite sure why the world needs two Decaturs.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: What are you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I live in Bakersfield now. But I got a job singing in Reno tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: That's exciting.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: That’s not exactly the word I’d use to describe a six o’clock shift at a keno lounge. But. It’s a job.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Why are you staying here? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 40.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: It’s not a good job. Don’t pay nothing. If I stayed in Reno proper I'd end up in the hole. Outskirts are cheaper.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Why do it at all? Darlene hesitates. Sadness in her eyes. She shrugs. I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Some days... I ask myself that same question. She recovers. He thinks

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Singin’s singin’, I guess. (then) How ‘bout you? How’d you end up at the El Royale?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I was up in Oakland. Visiting my brother. Making my way back to Indiana. Had to get off the road before dark. My eyes are bad at night. (then) Ritz-Carlton was booked. So here we are.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I’m guessing the church pays about the same as a Reno keno parlor?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: (nods ) About that.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: You and your brother close?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: We used to be. about it. Drinks. FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) We used to be. (then) (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 4l.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) Can I confess something to you, Darlene?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Isn't it supposed to be the other way ‘round?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: (smiles ) We can make allowances for that, if need be. But... (then) When I said my memory wasn’t what it used to be... I may have been understating things a tad. (drinks ) For the last few years, I’ve been having problems with my recall. And I don’t think it’s just my age. (then) I’m certain it’s not just age. “But how can they control you, Bernadette? When they cann control themselves, Bernadette?” FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) I wake up some days, and I can’t remember who I am. I have moments where I lose time... when you saw me in the parking lot, today, actually. I had completely forgotten where I was. What I was doing. It’s the strangest feeling. You look around and you’re someone else. And you don’t know who that is.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Father... can I say something? (then) It sounds like you should see a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I did. (smiles ) He agrees with my assessment that it’s not just age.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: (oh) I’m sorry. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 42.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then) I'm very sorry. He smiles a kindly smile.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I wasn’t looking for pity. Might be for the best, in fact. Some parts of my life aren’t worth remembering. No, I’m just telling you because, if I seem scattered... I don’t mean offense. She pats his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: None taken. Flynn finishes his drink. Exhales.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I could use another. He stands up. Makes his way back to the bar. She gets up, too. Carries their dirty plates over to the bar. FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) Sure I can’t tempt you? My memory may be spotty, but I do recall it’s a sin to let an old priest drink alone.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Okay, sure. One drink.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Grand. Darlene walks back over to the jukebox. CLOSE SHOTS: Flynn pours two drinks. Flynn glances up at Darlene. Confirms she’s not looking a him. She’s lost in the music. And in this moment, as he stares at Darlene, Father Flynn face changes. The kindly old priest disappears. And is replaced by a different man. A much harder man. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 19 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 43.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) Perhaps I could even tempt you to grace me with a song again later? Father Flynn reaches into his jacket and removes a small glass vial. He pours a clear liquid into Darlene’s drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darlene doesn’t see any of this happen.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: (back turned) Don’t push your luck, Father. But. If you happen to find yourself in Reno tomorrow... I go on at six.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I'd like that. HOLD ON FLYNN. His face drifts again. As though he’s forgotten, once again, where he is. Or. Perhaps he’s having second thoughts about what he’s about do. He repeats the words to himself, as though he’s realizing he really means them: FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) (quietly) I'd like that. But. Then. His face hardens with resolve. He picks up the glasses. He turns around... FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) But until then -- And Darlene bashes him in the face with a wine bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH! The bottle SHATTERS. Blood and glass flies everywhere. Father Daniel Flynn goes down in a wet heap. Darlene stares down at his unconscious body. On the jukeb we hear Levi Stubbs scream out:

dialogues.speaker: LEVI STUBBS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bernadette! CUT TO BLACK. TITLE: 950 Pennsylvania Avenue 19 We hear two voices: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 44,

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: ...in the process of retrieving our equipment, I discovered an additional wiretap and four microphones. TITLE: Washington, D.C. TITLE 5th Floor

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Did you recognize the equipment? Northeast Corner Suite

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: I do not believe it was ours, sir. TITLE Anteroom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HELEN GANDY began working for J. Edgar Hoover in 1918. Sh will remain his executive assistant until his death in 19 Her fingers fly across the typewriter as she transcribes conversation from earlier.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Upon investigation, I discovered the room also had a two-way mirror. I found similar rooms in this hotel, along with camera equipment.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Did you find film?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: No sir. I called as soon as I discovered the camera.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: No one is to leave there, Agent Broadbeck, until you have any and all existing surveillance materials in your possession.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Understood, sir.  20 21 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain is pouring down now as Dwight makes his way through parking lot. He’s watching the front carefully, he does n want to be seen. He slides up to Emily’s Mustang, pops the hood. Yanks the DISTRIBUTOR COIL CABLE free. Pockets it in his raincoat.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Dwight repeats the process on Flynn’s Futura.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Dwight repeats the process on Darlene’s Studebaker. He sh the hood... and stares at the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Sir... there’s something else. While investigating the observation corridor, I witnessed what appeared to be a kidnapping in process. A young woman, Caucasian, holding another woman hostage. Also Caucasian.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: The priority is the surveillance material, Agent Broadbeck. Peripheral matters are not our concern. Dwight stands in the rain. Staring at the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: Sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tape reels spin as Helen transcribes:

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER, (ON TAPE)
dialogues.text: I am not in the habit of repeating myself, Agent Broadbeck, but I will do so here to ensure there is no confusion.... CLOSE ON HELEN’S PAGE as her keys type: “DO NOT INTERFERE.”  22 23 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight stands in front of his mirror. Soaking wet. Breathing hard. Thinking. He glances at himself in the mirror. CUT TO BLACK. TITLE: Room Seven We HEAR the gentle sound of crashing waves...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A solitary trail of BOOT PRINTS leads up the beach to whe young eighteen-year-old girl sits beside a large Army duf It's Rose. She's wearing cowboy boots and jeans. She sits in the sand with her knees to her chest. She's crying. A BAREFOOT MAN walks along the boot prints. Theirs are th only footprints on the beach.

dialogues.speaker: BAREFOOT MAN
dialogues.text: Hi. Rose looks up and squints. The man is BACKLIT by the sett California sun. We never get a good look at his face.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: BAREFOOT MAN
dialogues.text: I like your boots.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: They’re my Daddy's.

dialogues.speaker: BAREFOOT MAN
dialogues.text: Don’t look like they’re your Daddy’s no more. (then) That why you're crying? Rose shrugs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 47.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BAREFOOT MAN (CONT’D) Don’t get a lot of girls down here in boots. You come straight from the station? Rose shrugs. BAREFOOT MAN (CONT’D) It’s all right, Boots. You don’t got to say nothin’. I/'11 figure it out in three guesses. Watch. Tennessee. Rose just looks at him. BAREFOOT MAN (CONT’D) Nah. Too easy. And you ain’t no Texas girl, I know that much for sure. West Virginia? (she shakes her head) ‘Course not. “Let’s not be insulting, Billy Lee.” Nah, I’m just messin’ about with you. I knew it the second I saw these bootprints in this beach. (then) You're an Alabama girl. OFF HER LOOK. BAREFOOT MAN (CONT’D) See. Told you I could do it in three. He takes his shirt off, drops it next to her. BAREFOOT MAN (CONT’D) Now you got to come swimming with me.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (smiles ) That wasn’t the deal.

dialogues.speaker: BAREFOOT MAN
dialogues.text: Sure it was. You knew the game the second we started playing. He unbuckles his belt. Slips out of his jeans. Naked. He walks towards the ocean. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23 24 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 48.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BAREFOOT MAN (CONT’D) C'mon, Boots. You got no reason to cry no more... CLOSE ON ROSE as she hears: BAREFOOT MAN (CONT’D) You’re in California now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAME FRAMING. CLOSE ON ROSE. Bound and gagged. Her eyes flutter. She groans. Emily looks up from across the room, where she’s busy stashing her gear under the bed. She hurries over to Rose kneels down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Rose? Rosie? It’s okay. You’re safe. You’re here with me. It’s Em. Rose’s eyes from fear to recognition to anger in a flash. She strains against her bonds.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rosie. Stop. You’re safe. But I can’t untie you. Not ‘til you’re right. We gotta get you right. (Rose struggles) I ‘spect you’re all kinds of mad at me. And some extent you're right to be. But we’re gonna wait this out. We’re gonna wait ‘til you’re clear. Then we’ll have it out. She kisses Rose on the forehead. Rose looks at her with malice.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I had to get you away from him, Rosie. He’s all kinds of bad. And we gotta get as far away from him as possible. You’1l understand. We just gotta get you clear... and you'll understand. And right then... there’s a KNOCK at the door. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 49,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Both jump in surprise. Emily hops to her feet, grabs her handgun. Locks eyes with Rosie. Holds a finger to her lip Shhhhh... Emily creeps to the door. We hear Dwight’s VOICE outside:

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ma’am? Hello? I’m so sorry to bother you. Emily looks through the keyhole. Frowns.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Ma’am, it’s Laramie Sullivan. We met earlier in the lobby. Would you mind opening up the door?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: No, I ain’t gonna do that.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Of course. I certainly respect that. Good to be cautious. We can talk through the door if that suits you.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Storm’s wreckin’ hell on the hotel. Gettin’ all kinds of complaints with people’s power and such. Boy up front asked me to help check on the women, make sure everyone’s safe.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: That’s good news. (then) Listen... if you wouldn’t mind --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Fuck. Off. There’s a long silence. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 25 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 50.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I’m very sorry to have spooked you, ma’am. Have a safe night. We hear footsteps walking away. Rose watches Emily in the mirror. Emily watches through the keyhole. Waits. Turns back towards Rose... And Dwight kicks in the door. Wham! The door hits Emily -- she spins to fire -- but bef she can, Dwight BACKHANDS her with the butt of his gun. S goes down hard, between the two beds. Her gun goes skittering across the floor. Dwight puts his foot on Emily’s gun. Kicks it into the bathroom. Keeps his gun trained on Emily. But she’s unconscious. Not moving. Rose CRIES OUT beneath her gag. Dwight hurries over to her.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s okay -- it’s okay. I’m the law. It’s all right... He reaches into his pocket. Pulls out a switchblade. Star cutting free her ropes.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re safe now. ON THE GROUND. Emily groans as blood drips from her templ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAME FRAMING. Eight-year-old EMILY on the ground. Blood dripping from her head. MAN’S VOICE Don’t touch it. Let it bleed. HER POV: we see THOSE BOOTS from earlier walking away fro her across the wood floor. The voice belongs to her father, HUTCH SUMMERSPRING. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 26 27 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 51.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MAN’S VOICE (CONT’D) Next time you want to get smart you look down at all that red and you think twice. Tears well up in Emily's eyes. HER POV: Hutch walks to the kitchen. Opens the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH
dialogues.text: Where's Rosie? Emily struggles to her feet. Races up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An angelic FOUR-YEAR-OLD is fast asleep in her bed.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: Rose? Rosie? Get up. It’s okay. Come with me. Downstairs. We hear glass breaking. The man yelling. Emily leads a half-asleep Rose to what looks like a guest room. There’s a four-post bed. She pushes Rose under the bed. Gets on her hands and knees. Looks Rose in the eye. YOUNG EMILY (CONT’D) Don’t you come out, okay? No matter what you hear, you stay put.

dialogues.speaker: HUTCH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where's Rosie? Rose’s POV: looking at her big sister from under the bed.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG EMILY
dialogues.text: No matter what you hear, don’t make a sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAME FRAMING. Looking at Emily from under the bed. She winces in pain. Her eyes struggle to find focus. She locks on something. She’s looking right at us. Emily’s POV: under the bed, a green army duffel. Sticking out of it: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 52.

dialogues.speaker: A SHOTGUN.
dialogues.text: ACROSS THE ROOM -- Dwight finishes untying Rose. Pulls th gag down out of her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: You don’t have any reason to be scared. You’re safe now.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (smiles ) Okay, good.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Rosie... They turn as Emily rises.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get out of the way. Rose steps aside. Revealing Emily. Pointing her shotgun. Right at Dwight. BOOM. The shot is DEAFENING. Emily shoots Dwight right in the chest. Both barrels. His chest explodes. Behind him, the mirror SHATTERS. Dwight’s body hits the ground in a bloody mess. Rose stares down at his dead body. Curious. Surprisingly calm for what’s just transpired. Emily struggles to catch her breath. Struggles to process what the fuck just happened. She lowers the shotgun. Look to the dead body. Looks to her sister. And then she looks to where the mirror used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because there’s not a wall behind that mirror. Instead, there’s A BLACK HOLE. And there seems to be sounds coming from that hole. Somebody is screaming. Emily and Rose look to each other. Look back to the hole. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 28 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 53.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Camera floats between the two girls... over Dwight’s dead body... towards what’s left of that mirror... and into th BLACK HOLE. CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAPID FIRE shots bring us back to earlier: The second-han on the wall clock ticks forward. Darlene grabs a wine bot from the rack. WHAM! She bashes Dock in the head. He crashes down HARD. CLOSE SHOTS: the mechanical arm chooses another record in Wurlitzer. Drops it onto the turntable. The needle hits t vinyl. We hear THE CRYSTALS start singing:

dialogues.speaker: THE CRYSTALS
dialogues.text: Well he walked up to me and he asked me if I wanted to dance... Father Daniel Flynn lies unconscious on the California si of the lobby. Broken glass and puddles of booze. THE CRYSTALS (CONT’D) He looked kind of nice and so I said I might take a chance... We hear footsteps. TENNIS SHOES run into frame.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Father? Oh no... It’s Miles. He races to Flynn’s side.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Father Flynn -- Father Flynn -- oh no no -- wake up -- Father -- Flynn groans as Miles pats his face. He gasps. Disoriente Shoves Miles away. Fear in his eyes. Tries to sit upright MILES (CONT’D) Father, don’t try to move -- Flynn looks at Miles with dazed eyes.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I’m not your father. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 54.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Take it easy. Take it real easy. You're hurt. What the heck happened? Father Flynn touches the wound on his head. Rubs the bloo between his fingers. His eyes drift as he listens.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: What’s this song?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Father... do you know where you are? Clarity starts to creep into Flynn's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: That’s what I’m askin’ you. I just found you like this. On the floor. You got glass in your head. Flynn picks broken glass out of his head.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Where's... where’s... (then) Was I alone?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Yeah. Why? Was you with somebody?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: (thinks; then) No. Flynn gets to his feet. But as he takes a step, his knees get weak. He manages to slide into the banquet. FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) Kid... what’s your name again?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Miles.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Miles. I need a drink. (then) Fix me a drink. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 55.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I’m not so sure that’s a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
