dialogues.text: Just one drink. To clear my head. I'd do it myself, but... (gestures to mess) Look what happens. Miles hesitates. Unsure. FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) I fell down, Miles. I’m old. Shit happens. Get the whiskey. Miles heads towards the bar. Flynn sits in the banquet an listens to the music. He catches a glimpse of himself in reflections on the wall. Sees the priest collar.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Father... I was hoping... (pours drink) I was hoping I could ask for your help. I been gone. I been gone from the church for a while now... He hands Flynn a glass of whiskey and a towel. MILES (CONT’D) But I was devout. My whole life. Baptized. Confirmed. Never missed a Sunday ‘til I left Indiana. Flynn drinks. Still a little woozy.

dialogues.speaker: FLYNN
dialogues.text: I was born in Indiana.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Really? No kiddin’. Whereabouts? Flynn doesn’t respond. He takes the towel and dabs his he Looks at his own blood. MILES (CONT’D) Father... I was hoping... see... (then) I got things I need to confess.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Not right now, kid. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 56.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Okay, Father. Right. Of course. It’s just... I’m penitent, Father, I promise. I’m penitent and I’m afraid for my soul. (then) I’ve done horrible things.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: So's everybody. You'll be fine. Flynn finishes the drink. Stands. Takes a few steps. He’s got his sea legs back. FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) You got a master key to this place?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Did you lock yourself out of your room?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: (nods ) Like I said, kid, I’m old. CLOSE SHOT: the drawer slides open, revealing the room ke

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Should be right here... But it’s not. There’s an empty hook instead. Miles looks distressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miles rummages through his cramped closet. Looking for th key. He can’t find it. Knows something’s wrong. Flynn watches over Miles’ shoulder. Miles sees Flynn look at his heroin rig.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Father... Flynn shrugs. Does a quick sign of the cross on Miles. You're forgiven.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Where’s the key? Miles shakes his head. Walks towards THE CORRIDOR. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 30 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 57.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I told you this wasn’t a good place, Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miles walks round the corner. Flynn follows. Stepping wit caution. What the fuck is this place? Miles stops in front of the first window. Head down in shame. Flynn steps forward. Sees it’s his room.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: You watched me? His eyes flash. He grabs Miles by the throat. Slams him u against the wall. Miles cries out in pain.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What did you see?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I didn’t see nothin’! I didn’t -- I only watch who they tell me to watch.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Who's “they?”

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Management. I get a call, “So-and- sos checking in, set up the camera.” Hasn’t happened as much since the election... Flynn's head whips around. He sees THE CAMERA down at the end of the hall. Flynn lets go of Miles. He starts walking towards the camera. Stops at the next room... Darlene’s room. MILES (CONT’D) Mostly they just want, you know, people... screwin’. It’s empty. No sign of Darlene anywhere. But the sound baffles are still on the walls. Flynn stares at them. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 58.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: What do you do with the film?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Develop it in one of the back cabins. Mail it to Management. P.O. Box in Pennsylvania. Hold on Flynn. His mind racing. He keeps walking down the hall. Miles follows.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: You ever keep any of the film? Miles doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miles.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Last year. The big celebration. Man stayed with us... he was known. A big deal. You know? Management wanted him. They really wanted him. But he was kind to me. So I told them there wasn’t no woman in his room.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: But_you kept the film? Miles doesn’t say anything. Tears start to well in his ey

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Father... this ain’t even what I was tryin’ to confess. I done so much worse than this... Miles puts his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Miles...? But something catches their attention. Light flickers, shadows move on the wall across from Room Seven. Miles steps forward. And stops right in his tracks. Flynn joins him. And we angle around to reveal: Rose. Bound and gagged. Right up close to the window. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 59.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Who is that?! Jesus. Emily crosses from the other side of the room. Squats dow next to her. Starts talking. We can’t hear her. Miles flips the intercom switch.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (IN ROOM)
dialogues.text: You're safe. But I can’t untie you. Not ‘til you're right. We gotta get you right...

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: We gotta help her. (then) We gotta help her, Father. Flynn stares at Emily and Rose. Mind racing. Makes his decision. Grabs Miles. Pushes up so he can’t see in the room anymore.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: What did you do with the film?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (panicked) Father, we gotta do something. We gotta help her -- Flynn speaks with a calm, gentle voice.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Miles. Listen to me. (then) The Lord wants you to tell me where the film is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flynn yanks the mattress off Miles’ cot. Sees the cinder blocks underneath. Lifts one up, revealing a little hidin place: Some heroin bindles. A bible. And_a_can of 16mm film.  32 33 34 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miles watches in growing horror as Emily stands with her handgun, talking to Dwight through the door:

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Fuck. Off.

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry to have spooked you, ma'am. Have a safe night. WHAM! Miles jumps as Dwight kicks the door open, BACKHAND EMILY across the room.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Father Flynn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flynn has unspooled a length of the 16mm film. He’s holdi it up to the light. He turns his head as he hears Miles screaming for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flynn comes hurrying around the corner, sees a panicked M down at the end of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Father Flynn get down here that vacuum man just busted down the door and he beat up that other girl and he's got a gun -- Flynn races forward.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Rosie -- get out of the way. We hear the cold metal RACK of the shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: Kid -- GET AWAY FROM THE WINDOW! KA-BOOM! The window EXPLODES in the shotgun blast. Miles disappears in a storm of BUCKSHOT and GLASS. Flynn jumps, slams on the brakes. Watches in horror as Mi hits the ground. HOLD ON FLYNN. Staring at the hole where the window used be. He looks down at Miles. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 35 36 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 61.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And Miles starts to move. His face is a mess of blood and glass and buckshot. But h seems to be alive. He CRIES OUT in pain. HOLD ON FLYNN. Frozen. Not knowing what to do. Miles crie out on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Ahhbhhh... help me... Flynn takes a step forward. Moving to help him. But then thinks twice. Flynn stops. He starts backing up. He turns and runs. We’re at the far end of the hall. He races past us, round the corner. And just as Flynn disappears from view -- Emily sticks the shotgun through the hole. Swings it towa us. Scans the corridor. Sees the bloodied boy on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Jesus Fucking Christ! CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOTS. The mechanical arm chooses a record. “Bernadette” starts to play. TICK! The clock ticks forward. WHAM! Darlene bashes Flynn in the face with the bottle. WHUMP! Flynn hits the ground in a heap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RING-RING. Darlene races out of the lobby, into the rainstorm. Panic on her face. Breathing hard. She scans the parking lot. Think, Darlene...  37 38 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darlene grabs her keys from her night stand. Grabs her purse. Looks to the rest of her belongings. No time. Leav them behind. She bolts towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUMBLE. The rain is a genuine deluge. The crashing sounds of water and thunder drown out all other noise. But Darlene creeps through the darkness nonetheless. Stepping carefully. Keeping an eye on THE LOBBY. She sees NO MOVEMENT through the windows. Okay, good. Breathe, Darlene. Breathe. Time to go. She turns to step out of the darkness, into t parking lot, when -- WHUMP. She hears something. A muffled thump in the parking lot. She turns, and sees -- Dwight. He just shut the hood of Flynn’s Futura. He’s making his over to the Studebaker. Darlene's car. Darlene stays crouched in the shadows. Watches in growing horror. What is this man doing? Dwight pops Darlene’s hood. He searches around in her engine. RIPS something out of it. Then Dwight steps forward. Stares at the hotel. HOLD on Darlene. Staring at this man. Standing motionless in the middle of the storm. It’s unsettling. Dwight walks to his room. Disappears. Darlene waits. Oh god, what did he do? She bolts through the rain to her car. Slips into the driver’s seat. Fumble with her keys. Hands shaking. C’mon, Darlene. She manages to get the key into the ignition. Turns it... Nothing. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 63.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The car’s dead. No. She tries again. Click. And again. Click. Nothing. And all the fear and panic that Darlene’s been keeping at bay, it all comes home. She starts pounding at the steeri wheel... No no no no NO... Hold it together, Darlene. She grips the steering wheel tight. What do I do what do do? She closes her eyes. Tries to keep her voice calm.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Dear Lord, please give me guidance. I am here in darkness and I need your light. She sees something outside. It’s Dwight again. He’s left his room. He’s heading towards Room Seven. Now what? Darlene watches from the covered darkness of her car: Dwi knocks on the door. Dwight seems to be having a conversat with the person inside. Dwight seems to be getting frustrated. Dwight steps away from the door. Dwight pulls HIS GUN out of his coat. Darlene’s eyes go wide as Dwight steps quickly to the doo and KICKS IT OPEN. Darlene JUMPS -- oh my god -- as Dwigh disappears into the room. Darlene opens her door. Moving on instinct -- through the rain -- staying covered. Trying to get a better look at what's happening inside that room. There's Dwight, cutting Rose free. There's Emily getting her feet. With a shotgun. Before Darlene can scream -- BOOM. Emily shoots Dwight. Darlene claps her hands over her mouth to stifle her scre Oh god NO. Darlene’s POV: Emily and Rose look at each other in shock Look to the shattered window. Emily steps forward. Cautious. She pokes her head through the hole. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 39 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 64.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Jesus Fucking Christ! The storm around Darlene makes it hard to hear exactly wh being said in the room. We hear distant screaming. Words come through muffled.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is this? (then) Keep your fucking hands where I can see them! What the hell is this? Emily thinks. Looks to Rose.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rosie. Stay right there.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Okay. Emily takes the shotgun, clears the remaining glass on th edge of the window. She CLIMBS THROUGH the hole, keeping her gun trained on t ground below. Then she disappears.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I said keep your hands where I can see them! HOLD ON DARLENE. Crouched in the pouring rain. Watching these strange horrors unfold: Rose steps forward. Looks through the hole in the window. Huh. A curious child. Then Rose turns away. Surveys the room. Something catches her attention... The telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the room now. We can hear things much clearer. Emily YELLING. Miles SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don't have a gun -- What are you doing? Jesus! You shot me in the face -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 40 41 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 65.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rose picks up the phone. Glances back towards THE HOLE. N sign of Emily. She dials a number from memory. Listens. When she hears the voice on the other end, her f LIGHTS UP with happiness. Speaks quietly:

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hi! It’s me. (listens) I don’t know. I’m with Em. She had me all tied up. I think she shot a cop.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What is this place?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: We're in a hotel. I don’t know. (smiles bright) You will? Okay, let me look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darlene watches Rose talk on the phone. Can’t quite make what she’s saying. Sees Rose start to open drawers. Looki for something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose holds up A MATCHBOOK.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: It says “El Royale.”

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Rosie -- c'mon --

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I gotta go. (smiles) Okay. See you soon. Rose hangs up. She walks back across the room. Looks down at Dwight’s lifeless body. Huh.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Get up! MOVE. We hear Miles CRY OUT in pain. Rose hops up on the window. Slips through the hole into t darkness. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 66.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing back here? HOLD on the empty room as the sounds of Emily, Miles, and Rose recede. Camera drifts back towards THE FRONT DOOR. Rain and lightning and thunder. Darlene’s head peeks into the room. She steps forward tentatively, eyes on that window, ready bolt at the first sign of movement. She creeps into the room. Heart pounding. Keep it together, Darlene. Eyes LOCKED on that window. She slides up next to Dwight’s dead body. Starts patting bloodied chest. Where is it? Where is it? There. She reaches into his jacket. Eyes still watching that window. Pulls out... The distributor coil cable. Actually, to be precise, she pulls out three distributor cables. And they’re all bloodied. And they look like they've been chewed with buckshot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darlene’s heart falls. Panic takes hold once again. Not right now, Darlene. Her eyes glance down to Dwight’s face. His glassy, empty eyes stare up at her. Get moving, Darlene. She starts to head back the way she came. But then she stops. Sees something across the room. There. On the floor... Dwight’s gun. Darlene grabs it. Bolts from the room.  42 43 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darlene pops the hood of her Studebaker. Stares at the engine. Looks at the bloodied cables in her hands. What do I do with these? She searches for where they might fit. Her hands shake. It’s dark. She can barely see the engine, let alone disce where the cable might go. She makes her best guess. Tries to lock one of the cables place. She closes the hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darlene gets in her car. Shuts the door. Her hands fumble for her keys. C’mom... c'mon... She puts the key in the ignition. Take a breath. Please. Darlene turns the key. The engine groans. But doesn’t turn over. She grips the steering wheel so tight her knuckles turn white.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: (closes her eyes) Lord... There’s a KNOCK at the passenger’s side window. Darlene CRIES OUT in surprise. She reaches into her coat, pulls out the gun, points it RIGHT AT -- Father Flynn. He’s at the passenger window. Holding both hands where Darlene can see them. Don’t shoot. I mean no harm. He gestures for Darlene to roll down the window. After a moment, she does. Never taking the gun off him.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I just want to talk. Can I get in? Darlene thinks about it for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I will shoot you in the face. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 68.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: I believe you. He doesn’t wait for further invitation. He opens the door Sits down in the passenger seat slowwwwwwly. He rolls up the window. He wipes the rain from his forehead. He stares at the hotel. FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) Well. (then) We're in a bit of a pickle here. Darlene just stares at him. Tries to keep the gun from shaking as she points it right at him. FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) I’m sorry I tried to drug you back there in the lobby. (then) I wasn’t trying to diddle you or nothing like that. I just needed to break into your room and I didn’t want to hurt you. More than need be, I mean. (then) No hard feelings about bashing me in the head, is what I’m saying. Flynn stares at the hotel. Thinks. FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) I'm pretty sure those girls just killed a cop of some sort.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: (nods ) They did.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER FLYNN
dialogues.text: You saw it? Darlene nods. FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) That his gun? She nods again. Flynn thinks. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 44 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 69.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) This is not so good for us. He looks at her. Almost as an afterthought: FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) I’m not really a priest.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Yeah. (then) No shit. CUT TO BLACK. TITLE: Room Four We HEAR what sounds like sleigh bells jingling. And is th some sort of Christmas music in the distance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAME FRAMING. CLOSE ON the man we know as Father Flynn. A least, we think that’s him... it’s hard to know for sure beneath that BLACK HAT and MASK he’s wearing. We should probably start calling this man by his real name now:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is DOCK O’KELLY. We start slowly tracking back... ROTATING as we do so... seems to be frantically shoving CASH into a familiar RED Cash seems to flip and flutter in the air around us... we keep pulling back... snowflakes drift in among the cash.. Dock turns, climbs towards us, and we reveal we are in: 1958. Small town, main street U.S.A. Christmas time. Festive lights frame the folksy storefronts. Decorations snowdrifts line the streets. And right in the middle of i all... A horrible car accident. AN ARMORED CAR has been flipped completely upside down by a black Chevy truck. It’s chaos. Smoke billows from the cars. Cash and snow drift through the air. Dock climbs out of the back of the car, moving fast, shotgun in one hand, red bag in the oth He looks to LARSEN ROGERS, who is similarly dressed in a suit, hat, and mask. Larsen is crouched down, looking at TWO UNCONSCIOUS GUARDS near the wreckage. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 70.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Are they dead?

dialogues.speaker: LARSEN
dialogues.text: They’11 live.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: (angry) Where'd you learn to drive?

dialogues.speaker: LARSEN
dialogues.text: They swerved.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: They tend to do that when you’re box sweepin’ ‘em --

dialogues.speaker: LARSEN
dialogues.text: “Stay on his fender.” That’s what you said. “I want ‘em scared.”

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Scared. Not... comatose.

dialogues.speaker: LARSEN
dialogues.text: (sheepish) Comas are scary. SCRREECH. A ROARING BUICK tears around the corner, expert swerving to a stop in the middle of the action. The third member of the team hops out of the car... FELIX O’KELLY. Dock's brother. The same man we saw at the beginning of the film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He surveys the wreckage. Steps towards Larsen. Angry.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Are they dead?

dialogues.speaker: LARSEN
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Where'd you learn to drive?

dialogues.speaker: LARSEN
dialogues.text: We've been over this -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 71.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Shut _your fucking mouth. Get the money. Not one more word. Larsen begrudgingly starts scooping up what loose money h can from the ground.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Felix) They ain’t dead.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Praise the Lord. We can’t leave this here... Felix hops behind the wheel of the wrecked Chevy. Turns i over. The engine groans and rumbles... but it starts. Fel slams it into reverse, pulling it free from the armored c He backs up a few feet, right next to Dock. The two men listen to the clanking engine.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Will it run? Felix just shrugs. Who the fuck knows? They stare at Lars as he scoops up the money.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Think the kid’s bent or just stupid?

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: I’m going with stupid but I’m willing to be persuaded. ACROSS THE WAY: ONLOOKERS peek out from a CHRISTMAS TREE

dialogues.speaker: DOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hang on, I better scatter these kids... Dock steps towards the Christmas trees. He RACKS the shot and yells at two children:

dialogues.speaker: DOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This’1l cut_your little legs off at the fucking kneecaps! The kids run. Dock turns back to Felix.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: You're starting to sound like Mom. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 72.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Don't start. In the distance, we HEAR SIRENS.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: What do we do, Dock? HOLD ON DOCK. Standing in the middle of this chaos. Thinking. Then.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Get out of the car, Felix. Dock opens the door. Hands Felix the RED BAG.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take the kid. Ditch the Buick at Rocklin and split up. I’11 lead them south and burn this once I’m clear. (then) We'll meet at the El Royale. There’s a moment as these two brothers stand in the cente the storm. Snow drifts down as they lock eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Felix... Dock glances at Larsen.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Play it close. Felix nods. Dock slides behind the wheel of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: You sure about this? CLOSE ON DOCK. As he stares out at the CHAOS.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: I got it under control.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Please rise...

dialogues.speaker: MATCH CUT TO
dialogues.text: 45 46 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAME FRAMING. CLOSE ON DOCK. Now cleaned up in a cheap su and tie as he stands up next to his lawyer and awaits his sentence.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Donald O’Kelly. On the charges of grand larceny and conspiracy to commit larceny, I hereby sentence you to fifteen years in the federal penitentiary. HOLD ON DOCK as he hears his sentence. Pre-lap the sounds of A MAN SCREAMING...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAME FRAMING. Though now Dock’s lying on his back. And he looks a decade older. His wild, terrified eyes look up at as he thrashes about in his bunk.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Where am I where am I where am I? His CELLMATE is a large, tattooed man named SAMMY WILDS. tries to roust Dock from what seems like a waking nightma

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: Dock, Dock -- stop -- hey -- HEY -- You're okay -- Dock sits up. Stares at his cramped cell. Confused. Terrified. Gasping for air. A frightened child.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY
dialogues.text: Same place you’ve been for the last ten fucking years. Cell Block Four. Just breathe... you’re okay... Sammy’s voice seems to be calming Dock down. We get the sense this happens a lot. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 46 47 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 74.

dialogues.speaker: SAMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (exhales) Jesus, Dock. We gotta do something about this. HOLD ON DOCK as he stares at his cell. Trying to remember who he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAME FRAMING. CLOSE ON AN X-RAY of a skull. DR. WILLIAM LAURENCE studies the X-Ray. Takes a drag off cigarette. Dock sits in a prison hospital bed. He’s wearing his pris clothes. One hand is handcuffed to the bed rail. He’s got black eye and a bandaged forehead.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: I think you should stop fighting with the niggers, for starters.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Mexicans. This time. And I didn’t do nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: I'd hate to see what it looks like when you do something. They tell me that boy down the hall may not walk again.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: They jumped me.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: Sure. Dr. Laurence stares at the chart. Lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: It’s not the fighting. Dr. Laurence takes a drag off his cigarette. Grave. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47 48 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 75.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: (agrees) It’s not the fighting. He wheels himself closer to Dock. DR. LAURENCE (CONT’D) Tell me about your family. Any history of dementia? Alzheimer’s? Dock nods.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: My mother. (then) Her father. Dr. Laurence offers Dock one of his cigarettes. Dock take it. Dr. Laurence lights it for him.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How long do I got? Dr. Laurence thinks. Smokes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: When are you up for parole?

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Six months.

dialogues.speaker: DR. LAURENCE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) You should make it ‘til then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAME FRAMING. Dock sits in the passenger seat. Stares out at the rain. Darlene keeps the gun on him.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Ten years ago, my brother Felix and I robbed an armored car in Sacramento. Job went bad. I think we got burned by our crew. I went to prison, Felix got killed at the meetup. Which was here. At the El Royale. We had a plan, case things went south. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 76.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bury the money in the floor of the room. When they found his body, they never made no mention of the money. (then) I couldn’t remember what room we said. Either four or five. It was true what I said back there about my mind not being what it was. I guessed wrong. So. I think there’s a whole mess of money buried in your room. (then) And I need your help to get it. They sit in silence for a bit. The rain pours down.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: And you expect me to believe all that. Dock considers her question.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Um. Well. It’s the truth. So there’s that. But... no. I get it. (frowns ) How’d you know I wasn’t on the up- and-up in the first place?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) You spend your life gettin’ shook, you learn to spot a shaker. Dock nods. Likes the way that sounds.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Is that from a song? Darlene shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What if you were wrong? You’d have bashed a priest in the face for no reason.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I'd find a way to forgive myself. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 77.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: (thinks ) I suppose I’d do the same if I was in your situation.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: And now? What would you do if you was me? Dock thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: I guess my first instinct would be to shoot this old man in the face and clear out of Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: You're dead right so far.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: But then I'd think that through. The cars don’t work, and this storm isn’t letting up. How far am I getting on foot tonight? People are gonna come looking for that dead cop soon enough. And I sure don’t want to be the black woman in the woods with the gun when they do. (beat) So. Then I start thinking about my other options. I suppose I could walk back in there and take my chances with those kids...

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I promise you I ain’t thinking that.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Which leads me to option three. Maybe I hear this old man out. Maybe he’s telling the truth. Maybe he can help me. (then) Maybe there really is money in my room. And maybe this old man... maybe he doesn’t have a lot of time left. And he’s fine with fifty percent of whatever we find in that floor. HOLD ON DARLENE. Staring at Dock. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 49 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 78.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I’m wrong, I can still shoot him later. But if I’m right, I just might survive this night. (then) If I’m right... I can walk out of here with enough money to change my life forever. Darlene stares at Dock O'Kelly. Seeing him for who he is. Seeing what he’s offering. She thinks. She glances at The El Royale. Then.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: How much money we talking about exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mechanical arm chooses another record. The needle hits vinyl. Click click click... “Give me a ticket for an aeroplane... ain't got time to t a fast train..." Rose stands motionless in the dead center of the room. Staring UP. It’s unclear why. After a moment, she exits frame... and returns with a CHA She seems to be building something. Her movement carries us over to Emily, who has tied up Mi in a chair across the room. She sits down across from him Looks him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: So what is this? Some sort of pervert hotel? Miles is in rough shape. His face peppered with buckshot glass. He’s whimpering. She slaps him out of it.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey -- c’mon -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 79.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: No? Yes? I don’t know. You shot me in the face.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Let’s be clear. I shot another man who had it comin’. You were back there being creepy and caught a face of buckshot for your trouble. Hold still. You got glass in your head. She looks over his wounds. Brushes some of the larger chu of glass away.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: How’s it look?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I honestly can’t remember what you looked like before this, but you should probably make peace with the fact that things have changed.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Are you gonna kill me?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (thinks ) How can I not, after what you've seen?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I seen worse. And I ain’t saida thing.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You've seen worse than a man gettin’ sawn in half with a shotgun? Miles thinks about it. His haunted eyes start to drift.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I seen all sorts of bad. In the background, Rose continues to build her project. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 80.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MILES (CONT’D) I seen a Senator beat up a whore so bad she had to shove her own stockings back where her teeth used to be, to keep from bleedin’ out through the mouth. I seen... I seen a junkie paint “Sorry” on the wall in his own filth, like that’d make it easier when I cleaned all that shit off his cold body. (thinks ) I saw a man lay with a wolf once. Guy drags a full grown, feral wolf on a choke-chain into his room. Ties it up to the bed. Then takes off all his clothes, climbs in bed beside it, and holds the thing all night. Like, it wasn’t sexual, but it wasn’t not sexual, either. (thinks ) Guy just lay there crying. Saying “Help me” while he held that wolf. All night. (then) I never told nobody ‘bout none of that.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (Jesus Christ) I ain’t so sure you shoulda told me that now. A beat. And then we hear Rose’s footsteps ring out as she begins to run... climbing up the furniture stack and leap into the air... Rose catches hold of THE CHANDELIER. She swings back and forth with glee, like a child at the playground. The light in the room swings back and forth, back and forth... Emily stares at Rose. JI can't even deal with this shit r now. She lights a cigarette. She and Miles watch Rose swi back and forth for a beat. Miles glances back at Emily.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (quietly) You don’t have to kill me. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 50 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 81.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MILES (CONT’D) What could I even say about you anyway? “Some girls shot a guy who was gonna shoot them?” I don’t even know your names.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I’m Rose! Miles winces. So does Emily.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Don’t tell him your --

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Rose Summerspring. (then) That's my sister Emily. Emily’s eyes fall. A hint of sadness now as she glances a Miles. They share a look. As though they both know what this means. Emily thinks. Then she picks up her shotgun and walks ove to the front desk. Miles watches Rose swing.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Miles. Miles Miller.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Miles. CLOSE ON THE LEDGER. Emily rips the page free. She looks the names. Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Where are the others?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON THE METRONOME. A finger comes into frame. Starts the pendulum rod. Tick... tick... tick... Darlene sits in a chair in the middle of her room. We sta creeping towards her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 51 52 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 82.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tick... tick... tick... She reaches up, grabs her hair. Pulls at it. It’s A WIG. She tosses it aside. She glances up at herself in THE MIRROR. Tick... tick... tick... She begins to sing.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I need love, love, to ease my mind... I need to find time, someone to call mine... Her voice is soft at first. Timid. Weak.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My mama said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily walks through the dark corridor. She’s carrying the shotgun. She walks past Room Four. Stops at Room Five. Sees Darlene sitting in the middle of her room. Hands in lap. Singing. Emily frowns. Flips the switch on the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (IN ROOM)
dialogues.text: «--no you just have to wait... she said love don't come easy, it's a game of give and take... Emily watches. Darlene takes up most of the window. We may notice the be behind her have been moved slightly. DARLENE (IN ROOM) (CONT’D) You can't hurry love... no you just have to wait. you got to trust, give it time... no matter how long it takes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE ROOM. Darlene closes her eyes. Voice starting to g STRONGER. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 53 54 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 83.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: But _how many heartaches must I stand? Before I find a love to let me live again... As she sings, camera starts to drift... behind Darlene... floor space between the beds...

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right now the only thing... that keeps me hanging on... ..-where Dock is busy trying to tear up the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--when I feel my strength, yeah is almost gone... I remember mama said... It’s tough goings. Dock has to stay low between the beds. He’s got the carpet torn up, and he’s trying to wedge the crowbar in between the boards.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can't hurry love, no you just have to wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily steps closer to the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: She said love don't come easy, it's a game of give and take...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON DOCK. Sweat dripping down his brow as he works.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: How long must I wait? How much more can I take? DOCK’S POV. Down the canyons of the beds, he has a clear view of Darlene in her chair. He watches her sing.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Before loneliness will cause my heart... heart to break? Darlene claps her hands. Stands up. Losing herself in the music now. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 55 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 84.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No I can't bear to live my life alone... She claps in time to the beat. Dock grabs his hammer.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I grow impatient for a love to call my own... She locks eyes with Dock for a moment while she dances.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But when I feel that I, I can't go on... She claps. Dock strikes his hammer at the exact same time

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These precious words keep me hanging on... She claps. Dock strikes.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I remember mama said... you can't hurry love... you just have to wait...

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: She said love don't come easy, it's a game of give and take... In the corridor, the claps and DARLENE’S VOICE cover any sound of Dock working. But Emily keeps watching.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can't hurry love... no, you just have to wait... she said trust, give it time... no matter how long it takes... (then) Now break... Tick... tick... tick...  56 57 58 59 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Song break. The room goes entirely silent. Just the sound of that metronome. Tick... tick... tick... Darlene sways. She catches a glimpse of Dock between the beds. Crowbar under the boards. Ready to pry. Frozen. Watching Darlene. Darlene squares herself to the mirror. Tick... tick... tick...

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: No, love, love... don't come easy... She walks towards the mirror. We follow.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I keep on waiting... anticipating... She's belting it out now. Her voice full of power. She walks right up close to the mirror... looks herself in th eye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like Emily and Darlene are standing nose-to-nose

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: For that soft voice... to talk to me at night... for some tender arms... to hold me tight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Darlene screams:

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I_keep waiting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily jumps back. Startled. But Darlene keeps swaying.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I keep on waiting... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 60 61 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 86.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She claps. It almost looks like she’s having fun.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But it ain't easy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON DOCK. As he pries up the boards under cover of Darlene’s singing.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: It ain't easy. But mama said... The board clears. There. Down in the dirt. THE RED BAG.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can't hurry love... no you just have to wait... Darlene sways back into Dock’s view.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She said to trust, give it time... They LOCK EYES. It’s there. Darlene’s eyes dance.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No matter how long it takes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily turns away.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: You can't hurry love... no -- Click. Emily shuts off the intercom. The world goes eerily silent once again. Emily walks through the halls. Stops at Room Four. It’s empty. She stares at it. Thinks.  62 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “I Think We're Alone Now” by Tommy James & the Shondells plays on the jukebox. The chandelier is now on the ground smashed. Rose seems unfazed. She pulls a log out of the fireplace uses it to light the braziers around the room.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Rose? That’s your name, right? Please, Rose... please don’t kill me. Rose stands motionless in the center of the room.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: It ain’t entirely up to me.

dialogues.speaker: MALIBU MANSION
dialogues.text: Same framing. Rose stands over what looks like a DEAD BOD

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You can talk to her. She’s your sister? She’ll listen to you.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: It’s not up to her, either.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Who’s it up to?

dialogues.speaker: MALIBU MANSION
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON ROSE. As she stares down at the body, we see the SHADOW OF A MAN in the WINDOW behind her.

dialogues.speaker: LOUNGE
dialogues.text: Rose doesn’t respond to Miles. She turns to light another brazier. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 88.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Emily enters. Deep in thought. She sets the shotgun down the front desk. She drums her fingers on the desk. Something about this i not right...

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Where’s the priest? She looks across the room. Miles shifts uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miles?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Emily moves towards him.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: But you know something, don’t you? She reaches into her pocket. Pulls out Miles’ heroin. Sla it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is yours? Miles nods.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want it? Miles stares at the heroin. Nods.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where’s the priest?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I_don’t know. I promise. I want to find him, too. Please. Tears start to well up in his eyes. MILES (CONT’D) Please. I’11 do whatever you want. Just let me talk to the priest when you find him. (then) Just let me talk to him before you kill me. In the background, Rose pirouettes on the border. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 63 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 89.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I been trying to tell him, we might not have to kill him. But it’s not up to us. Emily's face falls. Wait. What?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Who’s it up to? A CHILL runs down her spine as she looks to her sister.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rosie... what did you do? In the darkness behind Emily, the shadows MOVE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darlene and Dock slip out of Room Five. Darlene holds the gun, Dock holds the bag. They keep their eyes locked on T LOBBY as they creep towards the parking lot. They give each other a look. We did it. Darlene motions for Dock to wait. She creeps forward, sta at the front windows of the lobby. It’s DARK. Why's it so dark? She waits as the sound of thunder crashes around th We can feel Darlene’s heart pounding. Something is wrong. but, if we're gonna move, we better move now. Darlene tur to Dock... let's go... And_a_man has a knife at Dock’s throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darlene’s eyes go wide with shock. She starts to raise th gun... a hand whips out of the shadows behind her, grabs arm, puts a knife to Darlene’s throat... It all happens FAST in the flashing tempest of the storm. “Twelve-Thirty” by The Mamas & the Papas starts to play. I used to live in New York City... Everything there was d and dirty... A MAN approaches. He’s walking towards them though the deluge. As the lightning FLASHES, we catch glimpses of THIS MAN: He’s young. Late-twenties, if we’d had to guess. He's wearing a white shirt, open all the way to his navel. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 64 65 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 90.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He’s barefoot. His feet step through the parking lot with rhythm, as though he can hear music nobody else can. Darlene and Dock lock eyes. Stare at this approaching figure. Outside my window, there's a steeple... The man stops as he nears. Lifts his face to the rain. Bathes in the storm as though it was a warm shower. With a clock that always reads twelve-thirty... The man smiles. The music SWELLS to CRESCENDO.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN THE RAIN
dialogues.text: Howdy. CUT TO BLACK. TITLE: Billy Lee The four-part harmony sings: “Young girls are coming to t canyon...”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking STRAIGHT DOWN on a field of yellow wildflow A nude man runs through the field, cutting the frame. “And in the mornings I can see them walking..." We finally get a good look at HIS FACE. This is BILLY LEE. As he walks through the field of wildflowers, we can see group of mostly-naked followers behind him. We may see Ro back there. Billy Lee leads them through the yellow. Feels the sun.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: How long you lookin’ to stay with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy stares at Emily. It’s just the two of them. They’re both clothed. They walk through the dense oaks and eucalyptus trees. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 91.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Emily shifts under his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I'll be here as long as my sister is, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: You don’t get to be part of the family just ‘cause you’re kin. Why do you want to be here?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Rosie says you treat her good. I ‘ppreciate that. They come upon a large, gnarled oak. Billy Lee sizes it u starts climbing it. Emily watches.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: That's the second time you brought up your sister when I was askin’ ‘bout you. Don’t worry about Rosie. Rosie’s right where she needs to be. (climbs ) You comin’ up? Emily stays right where she is.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I’m fine. Billy Lee leaps from bough to branch to bough with relati ease. Clearly at home up in the treetops.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Don’t get me wrong. I know what you've done for your sister. She’d still be in that house in Alabama without you. So thank you. Sincerely. For sendin’ her our way.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (bristles) Rosie... she told you about where we come from?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Sure. Not that I particularly care. You know who else has a rough past, Emily? Fuckin’ everyone. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 66 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 92.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He climbs higher and higher.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These trees don’t care about your past. This canyon don’t care about your past. You want to be someone else? He rips free a handful of leaves, tosses them down toward Emily with flourish.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Poof! The leaves flutter all around Emily.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re someone else. The leaves settle. Billy Lee looks down at Emily with THO EYES.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or maybe you’re still you. (shrugs) I don’t know. We’ll see, I guess. Emily stares up at Billy Lee. He breaks gaze first. Smile

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You sure you ain’t coming up? CLOSE ON BILLY LEE. As he stares out from the bough. Leav framing his face.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can see the whole world from up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAME FRAMING. CLOSE ON BILLY LEE. The bonfire flames fram his face:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: What does God mean to you? He stares at the assembled crowd of HIS FOLLOWERS: All young. Nobody over thirty. Everybody half-clothed. Free. They drape over one another in the firelight. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 93.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is He some being in the sky? Do you pray to Him at night? Do you ask Him to watch over you? There’s Emily. Watching from the edge. Billy Lee starts t drift towards her.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is He here with us now? (then) Would you know God if he was standing right in front of you? He locks eyes with Emily.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or maybe... maybe there is no God. (mock whispers) Maybe it’s all lies. He turns his attention back to the crowd. Warm again.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I honestly don’t know the answer. Part of me thinks that if I just keep talking ‘til the drugs kick in, you all will think I’m insightful. Is it working? Give it a second. Everyone laughs. They're all enraptured by him.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I ain’t saying I got it all figured out. But. I do see the game. They define right and wrong and then make you choose. That’s how it all starts. With a simple choice. Which side are you on? Up/Down. Good/Evil. Right/Wrong. God... or no God. It’s simple. Just pick. (to Rose) Boots. Quick. Choose. Are you good or are you bad?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I’m neither.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: She's cheating. She knows what answer I’m looking for. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 94.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m giving a whole speech here, Rosie. In front of people. Don’t mess this up for me. (crowd laughs) They’1l get you to pick. You get older, the world changes. Sooner or later, you'll need something. And they’1l get you to pick a side. You won’t even know what happened. Watch. I/’11 do it right now. (locks eyes with Emily) I‘ll do it right now with my star pupil. He smiles. Turns to Rose.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boots, why don’t you come up here and help me out? He chooses another girl.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And Millie, why don’t you join us, too. We’re gonna have a tussle tonight. The crowd cheers, excited.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Been a while since we’ve had a tussle, right? Oh, but Rosie don’t want to tussle, right? She’s smart enough to know not to play the game, right? But this is how I get her. I dangle something she really wants. You two are gonna have a proper tussle tonight. And the winner... well, the winner gets to sleep in the big house with me tonight. How’d that be? And from the looks on both Rose and Millie’s faces, it’s clear this is quite an honor.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See? Now we got skin in the game, as they say. (then) What do you think, Boots? Want to play? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 95.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: So pick a side. Do want to be Right or do you want to be Wrong?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I'll be Right.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Then Millie will be Wrong. Let’s have ourselves an allegory. The girls nod. They size each other up and down. Billy circles the crowd. Positions himself so he’s between the girls and Emily.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You girls make sure you stop when I tell you to stop. Not like last time, Millie, you hear me. (then) All right, then. Have at it. The girls charge each other. It happens fast. They SLAM into each other and crash into the ground. It’s surprisin violent. Emily steps forward to help her sister. But Billy Lee steps right in her way.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Easy, Emily. She’s a big girl. She can take care of herself. Emily's eyes dart to her sister. ON THE GROUND: Rose belt Millie in the face. Millie claws at Rose. The crowd roars approval.

dialogues.speaker: BILY LEE
dialogues.text: (back to crowd) Now. Here’s the important part. While they’re fighting, what am I doing? Cause I sure as hell ain't fighting. What am I doing? I’m watching them. Gettin’ off on it. And then, while they’re distracted, I’m coming over here. I’m taking what’s theirs. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 96.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He goes over to where Rose was sitting. Grabs her bag. Pulls out her cigarettes, stuffs them in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: I’m the one already sleeping in the big house, and I’m robbing them blind. This is all mine now. And they don’t even notice, ‘cause they’re too busy playing my game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE GROUND. Rose spits blood as Millie cracks her. Emily steps forward, but Billy Lee flashes her a look tha says don't you fucking dare. Rose lets out a primal scream and head-butts Millie in th face. Millie goes momentarily limp. Rose rolls on top of her. WHACK. Punches her right in the face. WHACK. Hits her again.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right. But Rose doesn’t stop.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right, Rosie. Shit. He pulls Rose off Millie. Gestures to one of his lieutenants, WADE, to help up Millie.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You did good. Tussle’s over. Now love each other. The crowd cheers. People slap congratulations to Rose and Millie. Rose gives Millie a hug. Millie looks dazed. Beaten. Ashamed. Rose wipes her lip. She has blood on her face.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are we doing out here, anyway? We just a bunch of kids doing drugs and fucking each other in the woods? (thinks about it) That doesn’t sound so bad, actually, now that I say it out loud. (everyone laughs) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 67 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 97.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit, maybe we do have it figured out after all. Everyone laughs, cheers. Billy Lee lets the crowd settle. Billy Lee cups Rose’s face. Kisses her lips. Tastes her blood. Looks to the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe we won't play their game no more. (then) Maybe we won't listen to their lies. (then) Maybe the only truth in this world is here... He places his hand on his own chest. He puts his hand on the woman next to him. And the man ne to her. Goes down the line.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And here... and here... and right here. The crowd cheers. He circles back to Rose and holds her. locks eyes with Emily across the fire.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe. For tonight. We get to be our own Gods. The crowd erupts into cheers. Emily holds his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily stares forward as Wade cinches ropes tight around h Next to her, ANNABELL, a wiry woman in her twenties, is cinching ropes around a panicked Miles.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (looks to Dock) Bless me Father for I have sinned -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 98.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROMAN and FLICKER, two men in their twenties, are now bus cinching ropes around both Dock and Darlene. Across the room, in California, Billy Lee is on the couch holding Rose in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Kid, if you don’t shut up, I’m gonna tie your mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Father, please -- Billy Lee looks to Annabell. Do it. She takes the bandana from her neck and ties it around Miles’ mouth. Billy Lee kisses Rose. Smooths her hair. Picks up the red bag. And the film can. As he crosses, we get a better look at the room: Dock, Darlene, Emily, and Miles are all now tied in chairs near roulette table in Nevada. Billy Lee takes the red bag and dumps all the cash on the roulette table. He stares at Do and Darlene. Tosses the film can on the table as well. Darlene looks at the film can. Looks at Dock. What is tha Dock says nothing. Billy Lee stares at them. Thinks. He grabs THE LEDGER PAG

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: So I’m guessing you’re Father Flynn, which makes the dead guy in seven Laramie Seymour Sullivan. And you're Darlene Sweet, right? Though I suppose you could be Fuck You, but something tells me that’s my Emily here. Any other people in this hotel? The four of them trade glances. Eyes look to Miles. He shakes his head. No.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reads name tag) Miles. I’m gonna have my friends search this hotel. They find any other souls, you die bad. Understand? Miles nods. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 99.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Any other people here? Miles shakes his head. Billy studies him. Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Annabell, Wade. You two are on sentry. Stand behind these four. They try to get out of those seats, shoot ‘em in the back of the head. They do as instructed. Wade has a rifle. Annabell picks u Emily’s shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Flicker, Roman -- go get that body out of room seven. Find his car keys, stick the body and all his stuff in the trunk. After that, go room to room. Find anybody, bring ‘em here. In fact, you find anything of interest, you bring it here.

dialogues.speaker: FLICKER
dialogues.text: Define “of interest.”

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: “Oh wow oh wow, Billy Lee should see this.” Flicker and Roman nod. Head towards the door. As they go:

dialogues.speaker: FLICKER
dialogues.text: (re: the four) And them?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. But I’d leave some room in that trunk. Ding. Flicker and Roman leave. Billy Lee crosses to the bar. Pours himself a drink. Crosses back into Nevada. Sits down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hiya, Em. She stares at him. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 100.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Billy Lee.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: You left without sayin’ goodbye. She doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you think I wouldn’t take offense?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Naw, I figured you would. (then) But I’d be ready when you did.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: You don’t look ready.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You caught me on a bad night. Billy Lee almost laughs at that.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Ain’t that the luck. (then, quietly) You tell them what she did? Emily shakes her head. No.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What'd I do? (remembers ) Oh. Right. (then) I’m sorry ‘bout all that.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: That’s okay, Boots. We’ll deal with that when we get back to California. (looks around) We got us a Nevada problem now. Billy Lee takes a drink. Thinks. Looks to Miles.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what is this -- some sort of pervert hotel? The four sit in silence. Miles looks at a loss. What? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 101.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: The kid can’t answer you. You tied his mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Why don’t I ask you, then? Why don’t I ask the priest walking out of the hotel with a bag full of money?

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: All right. (then) Yes. I think it’s some sort of pervert hotel. (then) Kid told me he films people doing... what not, then sends the films off to his bosses.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Who are his bosses?

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: (shrugs) People who own the hotel? I don’t know. Does it really matter? Billy Lee studies Miles. Shrugs. I guess it doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: And he just offered this up to you?

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: I think he was trying to confess. I think it’s been weighing on him. (looks at Miles) I think he’s trying to confess right now. Because he knows how this is gonna go. And he fears for his soul. Tears well up in Miles’ eyes. He nods. That's right. Billy Lee rolls his eyes. Pats Miles on the face.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: If you’re so worried about your soul, kid, maybe you shouldn’t been doing all this bad shit in the first place, huh? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 102.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He opens the film can. Unspools the 16mm film. Holds it u to the light to get a better look. Squints. He jumps in surprise. Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that who I think it is? Miles nods.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Who? I want to see. Billy Lee tosses Rose the film. Studies Dock.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Now what’s a man of God like yourself doing with that in your coat? Rose holds the film up to the light.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: It’s just people fucking. (then) Wait... I know him. (then) He’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: (nods ) That he is, Rose. That he is. Billy Lee drums his fingers on his face. Looks to Darlene

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where’s the money come from?

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: It’s --

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: I_ain’t asking you right now, Father. (then) Where’s the money come from? Hold on Darlene. As she stares at these children around h Then. Defiant:

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: It’s mine. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: (laughs) It’s yours. (all right then) So where's a girl like you get all this money from?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I earned it. Singing.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: (okay) You must be one hell of a singer, then.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I am. She holds his gaze. 103. 67 After a moment, Billy Lee looks away. He turns his attent back to Dock.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Where’s the money come from?

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: She's telling you the truth. That’s her money. She earned it singing.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: And you’re a man of the cloth.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: I forgot to mention... Billy Lee finishes his drink. Leans in close to Stares at him with THOSE EYES.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I_hate priests. (then) You want to change your story? Dock doesn't flinch. Stares right back.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Nope. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 104.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hold for a moment. These two men staring each other down. Then. Billy Lee smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Alrighty then. He hops up.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boots, why don’t you find us something to listen to on that there jukebox. It’s too quiet in here. Gives me the willies. He grabs Dock’s change from where it fell on the floor earlier. Tosses Rose a quarter. She picks a song. “Hush” by Deep Purple starts playing. Rose and Billy Lee sway a bit to the bass line. HOLD ON DOCK AND DARLENE as the music plays around them. Darlene tense. Dock listening.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Who's this? Darlene looks at him. Realizes he’s serious.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: It's... Deep Purple. I think. But, it was originally someone else. Billy Joe Royal, maybe? Dock listens. Frowns. Shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: It’s not for me. Billy Lee crosses back over to the table. We may notice h has THE REVOLVER tucked into the front of his jeans.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: (to Dock and Darlene) I want you two to pay real close attention to what happens next. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 105.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And keep it right up there in the front of your mind when I ask you questions looking for truthful answers. He sits down at the end of the table close to Emily and Miles. He stares right at Emily.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Emily. (then) Pick a color. Red or black. Across the room, Rose looks up from the film. Emily stares at Billy Lee. Then she shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well that’s not hardly nice. I’m offering you a chance here on account of the fact that we’re practically family. That’s downright charitable of me, considering. (then) Boots, you hear what your sister's doing? Rose looks at Emily with sad eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Emily... if Billy Lee’s offering you a chance... you should take it. Billy Lee smiles. Nods. Locks those eyes on Emily.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: (leans in) Did you really think you could take what’s mine and I wouldn’t come a- huntin’?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: She ain’t yours.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: (oh yeah?) Rosie? Are you mine? Rose smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Of course! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 106.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Billy Lee shrugs. There you go. He pours himself another drink.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: We used to raise goats out on the farm. Boer goats, ‘cause you can breed ‘em year round. Bucks are ready to go once they’re about seven weeks old. Seven weeks! (looks to Wade) Can you imagine? Think of something that happened to you seven weeks ago. If you were a baby then, you’d be fucking now. (then) ‘Cause you’re male, I mean. The does take about eight months ‘fore they’re much use. And you learn. When you got a litter, you learn to separate the females before those bucks come ruttin’. ‘Cause once those does go into heat... they’1l kill each other. I seen it over and over. They’1ll bash each others heads until their brains spill out in the dirt. Happens with mothers-— daughters, too. Something about the blood, I guess. But it ain’t like the sisters. (then) Ain’t nothing as violent as sisters. He finishes his drink.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (quietly) None of that is true. Billy Lee looks at her. I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There wasn’t no violence ‘til you.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Maybe. Maybe not. But it’s there now, though, isn’t it? (then) Pick a color, Em. I ain’t askin’ again. HOLD ON EMILY. As she studies this man. As she looks to h sister. As she sees her sister nod. Do it, Em.. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 107.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Emily’s shoulders fall. Then.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Red. Billy Lee looks mildly surprised. Good. He gives Annabell look. She steps in closer behind the four.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Well then I guess that makes you black, alter boy. And Billy Lee spins the roulette ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone TENSES as they realize what’s happening. The bal whips around the wheel. Wade and Annabell lean in with th guns. Their eyes saying stay in your fucking seats. Miles coughs beneath his gag. Billy Lee takes pity on him

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got some prayers, you can say ‘em now. Billy Lee pulls down Miles’ gag.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Forgive me Father for I have sinned, please -- I done so much worse than you know -- Billy Lee starts laughing. MILES (CONT’D) Father Flynn, please, I have sinned and I repent --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dock stares at Miles. Genuine sadness on his face. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Kid... Clack. The ball slows in its revolution, letting out a sh crack as it bounces in the tray.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Father Flynn --

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Do you want to tell him or you want me to do it? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 68 69 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 108.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Clack.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Miles...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: He’s not a fucking priest, kid. CLOSE ON MILES. As Billy Lee’s words land. As he sees Doc finally, for who he really is. And he realizes he’s going Hell. Clack. The ball comes to a stop in the tray. Red.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, it looks like the Lord hasn’t forsaken you yet. Billy Lee pulls his revolver. And shoots Emily right in the chest. BANG BANG BANG. She pitches straight backwards. Knocking over Miles. She crashes to the floor. We’re CLOSE ON HER as she hits the ground. On impact, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG EMILY screams out as her sister is ripped out from under the bed beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily’s eyes look up to her sister. Billy Lee steps in beside Rose.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: I gave her a fair shake, Rose. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 70 71 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 109.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON ROSE, as she nods --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG ROSE, in her father’s arms, stares back at her sist as she’s carried away. Her father holds her close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy Lee holds Rose. Emily’s eyes go dim. ON MILES. On the ground, rocking back and forth. Crying. Hands still bound in front of him. Staring at Emily’s dea body.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Now then. Who wants to play next? Darlene and Dock tense in their seats.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah ah -- Wade, Annabell -- keep a close eye there. Everyone’s liable to get more squirrelly now that they know the stakes. (to Dock) She'll cut you in half with that shotgun. Billy Lee sits down across from Dock and Darlene. Grabs t roulette ball. Tosses it back and forth in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You two gonna be more forthcoming? Dock thinks about it. Nods.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: Sure. (then) Could I have some of that whiskey?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: (studies him) Why not. (then) Boots! Get the padre here a glass. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 110.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She does. As she crosses back to the table, her eyes ling on the body of her dead sister. Miles whimpers on the ground. He’s muttering something to himself as he rocks b and forth.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kid, you don’t shut the fuck up, I’m gonna make you play again. Miles quiets down. Rose puts the glass on the table. Bill Lee pours Dock a drink. Dock’s hands are tied behind his back. He doesn’t know wh to do. Rose looks at Billy Lee. You want me to untie him?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. His hands stay tied. Billy Lee picks up the drink. Holds it to Dock’s lips. Do drinks.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where’s the money from?

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: I stole it from a bank about a decade ago. I hid it here, but got myself caught by the cops. Did some time. Got out a few days ago. Came back tonight to retrieve it. And he says it real matter-of-fact. So much so, it takes Billy Lee a second to absorb it. Then he laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: Tonight. Dock nods.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why you dressed up like a priest? ON MILES. Watching Dock across the room.

dialogues.speaker: DOCK
dialogues.text: I didn’t want too many questions. People tend to look the other way when you're wearing a collar. Billy Lee nods. Satisfied. Looks to Darlene.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: And you? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 111.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Darlene shifts a bit in her seat.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: I’m just a singer. The money happened to be hid in my room. He said he'd split it with me if I helped him get it back.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: ‘Course he did. ‘Cause that ain’t even the real score, is it, padre? No, ‘cause you found this. Billy Lee picks up the film. Brings it back to the table.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Darlene) I bet he didn’t tell you about this, did he? Don’t you even want to see who’s on it?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: No. I don’t. It doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: (laughs) Darlin’, then you ain’t understandin’ what’s on this --

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Stop. Stop talking. (then) I don’t need to look at the film. Let me guess: it’s some man who talks a lot. He talks so much he thinks he believes in something. But really... he just wants to fuck who he wants to fuck. (then) I’ve seen that enough. I’m not even angry about it anymore. I’m just tired. I’m just bored. of men like you. You think I don’t see you for what you are? A fragile little man. Preying on the weak and the lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to speak, but she cuts him off --

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've heard it. I don’t care. (beat) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 112.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd rather sit here and listen to the rain. Billy Lee’s eyes flash. Darlene doesn’t blink. The whole room seems to hold its breath. We hear the rain outside. It seems to be getting louder. Then. Billy Lee breaks Darlene’s gaze. The violence in his eyes vanishes as quickly as it appeared. He throws a patronizi shrug Darlene’s way --

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE
dialogues.text: You go right ahead. And turns his attention back to Dock.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY LEE, (CONT'D)
